english: Reducing corruption takes a specific kind of investment
yoruba: Mímú àdínkù bá iwà-ìbàjẹ́ gba irúfẹ́ ìdókówò kan tó yátò.

english: So in 2011, someone broke into my sister's office at the university where she teaches in Nigeria.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 2011, ẹnìkan lọ fọ́ ọ́fíísì ẹ̀gbọ́n mi lóbìnrin ní fásitì tí wón ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ olùkọ́ni ní orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà .

english: Now thankfully, the person was caught, arrested and charged to court.
yoruba: Ní báyìí a dúpẹ́, ọwọ́ ba ẹni náà, wọ́n mú u wọ́n sì gbe lọ sílé-ẹjọ́.

english: When I get into court, the clerks who were assigned to my sister's case informed her that they wouldn't be able to process the paperwork unless she paid a bribe.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo dé inú ilé-ẹjọ́, akọ̀wé tí wọ́n yàn sídi ìgbẹ́jọ́ ẹ̀gbọ́n mi fi tó wọn léti wí pé àwọn ò ní lè ṣiṣẹ́ lórí àwọn ìwe wọn àyàfi tí wọ́n bá san owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́.

english: Now, at first she thought it was part of a practical joke.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, ní ákọ̀kọ́ wọ́n rò wí pé lára àwàdà lásán ni.

english: But then she realized they were serious.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà náà wọ́n rí i wí pé wọ́n mú u lọ́kùkúdùn.

english: And then she became furious.
yoruba: Ni inú bá bí wọn.

english: I mean, think about it: here she was, the recent victim of a crime, with the very people who were supposed to help her, and they were demanding a bribe from her.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nipa pé, ẹ ronú sí i: àwọn rè é, ẹni tó ṣẹ̀sẹ̀ lùgbàdi ìwà ọ̀daràn, pẹ̀lú àwọn ènìyàn gaan tó yẹ kí wọ́n ràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́, wọ́n sì tún bèrè owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn.

english: That's just one of the many ways that corruption impacts millions of people in my country.
yoruba: Ọ̀kan nìyẹn nínú àwọn ọ̀nà tí ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ ti ń nípa lára mílíọ́nù àwọn ènìyàn ní orílẹ̀-èdè mi.

english: You know, growing up in Nigeria, corruption permeated virtually every element of the society.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà ní orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà , ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ fẹ́rẹ̀ gba gbogbo ǹkan inú àwùjọ lááyè.

english: Reports of politicians embezzling millions of dollars were common.
yoruba: Ìròyìn nípa àwọn olóṣèlú tí wọ́n kó mílíọ́nu dọ́là jẹ wọ́pọ̀.

english: Police officers stealing money or extorting money from everyday hardworking citizens was routine practice.
yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́pà tí wọ́n ń jí owó tàbí tí wọ́n ń lọ́wó gbà lọ́wọ́ àwọn ará ìlú tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ kára lójoojúmọ́ jẹ́ ìṣesí ojoojúmọ́.

english: I felt that development could never actually happen, so long as corruption persisted.
yoruba: Mó rò wí pé ìdágbàsókè ò ní ṣẹlẹ̀ láyéláyé, lódiwọ̀n ìgbà tí ìwà ìbàjẹ́ bá ṣì ń tẹ̀ síwájú.

english: But over the past several years, in my research on innovation and prosperity, I've learned that corruption is actually not the problem hindering our development.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n láti bí ọdún mélòó kan sẹ́yìn, nínú ìwádìí mi lórí ìṣẹ̀dá ǹkan-ọ̀tun àti ìdàgbàsóke, mo ṣàkíyèsí wí pé ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ kọ́ ni ìṣòro tó ń ṣe ìdèna ìdàgbàsókè wa.

english: In fact, conventional thinking on corruption and its relationship to development is not only wrong, but it's holding many poor countries backwards.
yoruba: Ní òtítọ́, ìrònú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nípa ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ àti àjọṣepọ̀ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìdàgbàsókè kò lòdì nìkan, ó ń fa ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́ n kúṣẹ̀ sẹ́yìn.

english: So, the thinking goes like this: in a society that's poor and corrupt, our best shot at reducing corruption is to create good laws, enforce them well, and this will make way for development and innovation to flourish.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, Ìrònú náà lọ báyìí: ní àwùjọ tó kúṣẹ̀ tí wọ́n sì ní ìwà-ìbàjẹ́, ìgbìyànjú wa tó dára jù láti mú àdínkù bá ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ ni láti ṣẹ̀dá àwọn ọ̀fin gidi, ká lòwọ́n dáadáa, èyí ó sì ṣínà fún ìdàgbàsókè àti ìṣẹ̀dá ǹkan ọ̀tun láti gbòòrò si.

english: Now, it makes sense on paper, which is why many governments and development organizations invest billions of dollars annually on institutional reform and anti-corruption programs.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, ó mú ọpọlọ dání lórí ìwé, ló fà á tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìjọba àti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìdàgbàsókè ṣe ń ná bílíọ́nù dọ́là lọ́dọọdún lórí àtúnṣe ilé-iṣẹ́ àti àwọn ètò tó ń gbógun ti ìwà-ìbàjẹ́.

english: But many of these programs fail to reduce corruption, because we have the equation backwards.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ètò wọ̀nyí kùnà láti mú àdínkù bá iwà-ìbàjẹ́, nítorí a ti to ọ̀rọ̀ wa lẹ́yìn-lẹ́yìn.

english: You see, societies don't develop because they've reduced corruption.
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ ríi, àwùjọ ò kí ń dàgbà sókè nítorí wọ́n ti mú àdínkù bá ìwà-ìbàjẹ́.

english: They're able to reduce corruption because they've developed.
yoruba: Wọ́n mú àdínkù bá ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ nítorí wọ́n ti dàgbà sókè ni.

english: And societies develop through investments in innovation.
yoruba: Àwùjọ sì máa ń dàgbàsókè nípasẹ̀ ìdókówò nínu ìṣẹ̀dá.

english: Now, at first, I thought this was impossible.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, ní àkọ́kọ́, mo rò wí pé èyí ò ṣe é ṣe ni.

english: Why would anyone in their right mind invest in a society where, at least on the surface, it seems a terrible place to do business?
yoruba: Báwo ni ẹnìkan tí ọpọlọ rẹ̀ẹ́ pé ṣe lè dókówò ní àwùjọ tí, ó kéré jù lérèfé, ó dàbi àyè tó burú jáì láti ṣòwò.

english: You know, a society where politicians are corrupt and consumers are poor?
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, àwùjọ tí àwọn olóṣèlú ti jẹ́ oníwà ìbàjẹ́ tí àwọn oníbàráà sì ti kúṣẹ̀?

english: But then, the more I learned about the relationship between innovation and corruption, the more I started to see things differently.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n, bí mo ṣe ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ síi nípa àjọṣepọ̀ láàrín ìṣẹ̀dá àti ìwà-ìbàjẹ́, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ní mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní rí ǹkan lọ́nà tó yátọ̀.

english: Here's how this played out in sub-Saharan Africa as the region developed its telecommunications industry.
yoruba: Báyìí ni èyí ṣe ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ìwò-oòrùn ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bí agbègbè náà ṣe ń ṣe ìdàgbàsókè ẹ̀ka ìbáraẹnisọ̀rọ rẹ̀.

english: In the late 1990s, fewer than five percent of people in sub-Saharan Africa had phones.
yoruba: Ní òpin àsìko ọdún 1990s, àwọn ènìyàn tó dín ní ìdá márùn-ún ní ìwọ̀-oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí wọ́n ní ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀.

english: In Nigeria, for example, the country had more than 110 million people but fewer than half a million phones in the whole nation.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà , fún àpẹẹrẹ, orílẹ̀-èdè náà ní ju ààdọ́fa mílíọ́nù ènìyàn lọ ṣùgbọ́n ó dín ní ìdàjì mílíọ́nù ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀ro ̣̀ tó wà ní gbógbo orílẹ̀-èdè náà.

english: Now, this scarcity fueled widespread corruption in the industry.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, ọ̀wọ́n yìí jẹ́ kí ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ tàn kálẹ̀ ní ẹ̀ka náà.

english: I mean, public officials who worked for the state-owned phone companies demanded bribes from people who wanted phones.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa, àwọn aṣojú ìjọba tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ìjọba tí wọ́n ń bère owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn ti ́ wọ́n fẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀.

english: And because most people couldn't afford to pay the bribes, phones were only available to those who were wealthy.
yoruba: Nítorí pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ò lè san owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ náà, àwọn tí wọ́n lówó ni èrò ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ náà ṣí sílẹ̀ fún.

english: Then an entrepreneur named Mo Ibrahim decided that he would set up a telecommunications company on the continent.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni oníṣówò kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mo Ibrahim bá pinnu pé òun yóò dá ilé-iṣẹ́ ìbáraẹnisọ̀rọ̀ sílẹ̀ ní ẹkùn náà.

english: Now, when he told his colleagues about his idea, they just laughed at him.
yoruba: Báyìí, nígbà tó sọ fún àwọn ọgbà rẹ̀ nípa èrò rẹ̀, wọ́n kò fi ṣe yẹ̀yẹ́ ni.

english: But Mo Ibrahim was undeterred.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n Mo Ibrahim kò jákàn.

english: And so in 1998, he set up Celtel.
yoruba: Nítorí náà ní ọdún 1998, ó dá Celtel sílẹ̀.

english: The company provided affordable mobile phones and cell service to millions of Africans, in some of the poorest and most corrupt countries in the region -- I mean countries such as Congo, Malawi, Sierra Leone and Uganda.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ náà pèse èrọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèká àti iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ tó rọjú fún mílíọ́nù ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀jùlọ tí wọ́n sì ní ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ jùlọ ní ẹkùn náà -- mò ń sọ nípa orílẹ̀-èdè bi Congo, Malawi, Sierra Leone àti Uganda.

english: You see, in our research, we call what Mo Ibrahim built a "market-creating innovation.
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ rí i, nínú ìwádìí wa, a pe ǹkan tí Mo Ibrahim ṣẹ̀dá ni "ìṣẹ̀dá tó ń ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ ọjà.

english: Market-creating innovations transform complicated and expensive products into products that are simple and affordable, so that many more people in society could access them.
yoruba: " ìṣẹ̀dá tó ń ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ ọjà máa ń ṣe àyípadà àwọn èròjà àmúdijú tó wọ́n di àwọn èròjà tó rọrùn tí ò sì ga ju ara lọ, kí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn nínú àwùjọ lè ní ànfàní sí wọn.

english: Now in this case, phones were expensive before Celtel made them much more affordable.
yoruba: Báyìí ní ti ọ̀rọ yìí, àwọn ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ wọ́n ṣíwájú kí Celtel tó sọ wọ́n di èyí tí ò ga ju ara lọ.

english: As other investors -- some of his colleagues, actually -- saw that it was possible to create a successful mobile phone company on the continent, they flooded in with billions of dollars of investments.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn olókówò míràn -- àwọn kan nínú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ rẹ̀, lóòtọ́ -- rí i wí pé ó ṣe é ṣe láti ṣẹ̀da ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèká ní àṣeyọrí ní ẹkùn náà, wọ́n rọ́ wọlé pẹ̀lú ìdókówò tó tó bílíọ́nù dọ́là.

english: And this led to significant growth in the industry.
yoruba: Èyí sì yọrí sí ìdàgbàsókè tó ṣe pàtàkì ní ẹ̀ka náà.

english: From barely nothing in 2000, today, virtually every African country now has a vibrant mobile telecommunications industry.
yoruba: Láti àìfẹ́rẹ̀ sí ǹkankan ní ọdún 2000, lónìí, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé gbogbo orílẹ̀ èdè ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwò ni wọ́n ti ní ẹ̀ka ìbáraẹnisọ̀rọ̀ to múná dóko.

english: The sector now supports close to one billion phone connections, it has created nearly four million jobs and generates billions of dollars in taxes every year.
yoruba: Ẹ̀ka náà ti wá ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn tó súmọ́ bílíọ́nù kan fún ìsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀, ó ti pèsè tó mílíọ́nù mẹ́rin iṣẹ́ ó sì ti pèse bílíọ̀nu dọ́là owó-orí lọ́dọọdún.

english: These are taxes that governments can now reinvest into the economy to build their institutions.
yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí ni owó-orí tí àwọn ìjọba lè wá tún dà sínú ọrọ̀-ajẹ́ láti kọ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ wọn.

english: And here's the thing: because most people no longer have to bribe public officials just to get a phone, corruption -- at least within this industry -- has reduced.
yoruba: Ǹkan ọ̀hún rèé: nítorí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ò nílò láti fún àwọn aṣojú ìjọba ní owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ láti gba ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀, ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ =--@ ókéré tán láàrín ẹ̀ka náà -- ti dínkù.

english: Now, if Mo Ibrahim had waited for corruption to be fixed in all of sub-Saharan Africa before he invested, he would still be waiting today.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, tó bá jẹ́ wí pé Mo Ibrahim ti dúró pé kí wọ́n wá ìyanjú sí ìwà-ìbájẹ́ ní ìwọ̀-oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ kó tó dókówò ni, yóó sì ma dúró dòní.

english: You know, most people who engage in corruption know they shouldn't.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń hu ìwà ìbàjẹ́ mọ̀ pé kò yẹ.

english: I mean, the public officials who were demanding bribes from people to get phones and the people who were paying the bribes -- they knew they were breaking the law.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa, àwọn aṣojú ìjọba tí wọ́n ń bèèrè fún owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn láti gba ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn tí wọ́n ń san owó ìbọ̀bẹ́ pẹ̀lú -- wọ́n mọ̀ wípé àwọn ń rú òfin ni.

english: But they did it anyways.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ṣà ṣe é ṣá.

english: The question is: Why?
yoruba: Ìbéérè náà ni, torí kíni?

english: The answer?
yoruba: Ìdáhùn rẹ̀?

english: See, whenever people would benefit from gaining access to something that scarce, this makes corruption attractive.
yoruba: Ẹ wòó, ìgbàkúùgbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bá ti máa rí ànfàní látara ìní ànfàní sí ǹkan tó ṣọ̀wọ́n, èyí máa ń jẹ́ kí ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ wọjú.

english: You know, in poor countries, we complain a lot about corrupt politicians who embezzle state funds.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀, a máa ń ṣe asọ̀ púpọ̀ nípa àwọn olóṣèlú oníwà ìbàjẹ́ tí wọ́n ń kó owó orílẹ̀-èdè jẹ.

english: But in many of those countries, economic opportunity is scarce, and so corruption becomes an attractive way to gain wealth.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọ̀n orílẹ̀-èdè wọ̀yẹn, ànfàní ọrọ̀-ajé ṣọ̀wọ́n, nitorí náà ni ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ fi di ọ̀nà tó wọjú láti jère ọrọ̀.

english: We also complain about civil servants like police officers, who extort money from everyday hardworking citizens.
yoruba: A tún máa ń ṣe asọ̀ nípa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba bí ọlọ́pà, tí wọ́n ń lọ́wó gbà lọ́wọ́ àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára lójoojúmọ́.

english: But most civil servants are grossly underpaid and are leading desperate lives.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba ni owó-oṣù wọ́n kéré jọjọ tí wọ́n sì ń gbé ìgbéayé àìbìkítà.

english: And so for them, extortion or corruption is a good way to make a living.
yoruba: Nítorí náà fún wọn, ìlọ́ni-lọ́wọ́-gbà tàbí ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ jẹ́ ọ̀na kan tó dára láti rí owó.

english: You know, this phenomenon also plays itself out in wealthy countries as well.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, ǹkan yìí tún máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n rọrọ̀ bákan náà.

english: When rich parents bribe university officials --
yoruba: Nigbà tí àwọn òbí tó lówó bá ń fún àwọn aṣojú fásitì ní owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́.

english: When rich parents bribe university officials so their children can gain admission into elite colleges, the circumstance is different, but the principle is the same.
yoruba: Nigbà tí àwọn òbí tó lówó lọ́wọ́ bá ń fún àwọn aṣojú fásitì ní owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ kí àwọn ọmọ wọn lè rí àyè wọlé sí àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ tó lórúkọ, ohun tó rọ̀ mọ́ èyí yátọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n bákan náà ni ìlàna wọn.

english: I mean, admission into elite colleges is scarce, and so bribery becomes attractive.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, ìgbaniwọlé sí àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ tó lórúkọ ṣọ̀wọ́n, nítorí náà ni owó ìbọ̀bẹ́ ṣe wọjú.

english: The thing is, I'm not trying to say there shouldn't be things that are scarce in society or things that are selective.
yoruba: Ǹkan náà ni wí pé, mi ò gbìyànjú láti sọ wí pé kó má sìí àwọn ǹkan tó ṣọ̀wọ́n láwùjọ tàbí àwọn ǹkan tí wọ́n máa ń yọbọ.

english: What I'm just trying to explain is this relationship between corruption and scarcity.
yoruba: Ǹkan tí mò ń gbìyànjú láti ṣàlàyé ni àjọṣepọ̀ yìí láàrín ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ àti ọ̀wọ́n.

english: And in most poor countries, way too many basic things are scarce.
yoruba: Ní ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ǹkan kòṣeé-má-nì ni wọ́n ṣọ̀wọ́n.

english: I mean things like food, education, health care, economic opportunity, jobs.
yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa àwọn ǹkan bí oúnjẹ, ètò ẹ̀kọ́, ajẹmọ́ ìtọ́jú ìlera, ànfàni ọrọ̀-ajé, iṣẹ́.

english: This creates the perfect breeding ground for corruption to thrive.
yoruba: Èyí pèse ilẹ̀ ọlọ́ràá fún ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ láti tayọ.

english: Now, in no way does this excuse corrupt behavior.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, kò sí ọ̀nà tí èyí fi jẹ́ àwíjàre fún ìwà-ìbàjẹ́.

english: It just helps us understand it a bit better.
yoruba: Ó kọ̀ ràn wá lọ́wọ́ láti ní òye nípa rẹ̀ si.

english: Investing in businesses that make things affordable and accessible to so many more people attacks this scarcity and creates the revenues for governments to reinvest in their economies.
yoruba: Ìdókówò nínu okòwò tó má a ń jẹ́ kí ǹkán rọjú kí ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyán sì ní ànfàní sí i máa ń kojú ọ̀wọ́n yìí ó sì máa ń pèse owó fún àwọn ìjọba láti tún dókówò nínú ọrọ̀-ajé wọn.

english: Now, when this happens on a countrywide level, it can revolutionize nations.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, nígbà tí èyí bá sẹlẹ̀ yíká orílẹ̀-èdè, ó lè mú àyípadà bá àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè.

english: Consider the impact in South Korea.
yoruba: Ẹ ro ipa rẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède South Korea.

english: Now, in the 1950s, South Korea was a desperately poor country, and it was very corrupt.
yoruba: Báyìí, ní àsìko ọdún 1950, orílẹ̀-ède South Korea jẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè kan tó kúṣẹ láìsí ìrètí, wọ́n sì ní ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ tó pọ̀.

english: The country was ruled by an authoritarian government and engaged in bribery and embezzlement.
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè náà wà lábẹ́ ìdarí ìjọba apàṣẹ wàá wọ́n sì ń kópa nínu owó-ìbọ̀bẹ́ àti ìkówó jẹ.

english: In fact, economists at the time said South Korea was trapped in poverty, and they referred to it as "an economic basket case.
yoruba: Lóòtọ́, àwọn onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ní àsìkò náà sọ wí pé orílẹ̀-ède South Korea ti wọ panpẹ́ òṣì, wọ́n sì ń tọ́ka sí wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bi "àpótí apẹ̀rẹ ọrọ̀-ajé.

english: When you looked at South Korea's institutions, even as late as the 1980s, they were on par with some of the poorest and most corrupt African countries at the time.
yoruba: Tí ẹ bá wo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-ède South Korea, kódà di òpin àsìko 1980, wọ́n wà ní ọgba pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Adúláwọ̀ tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀ tí wọ́n sì ń hu ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ jùlọ ní àsìkò náà.

english: But as companies like Samsung, Kia, Hyundai invested in innovations that made things much more affordable for so many more people, South Korea ultimately became prosperous.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n bí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ bi Samsung, Kia, Hyundai ṣe dókówò nínu ìṣẹ̀dá tó jẹ́ kí àwọn ǹkan túbọ̀ rọjú fún ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn, orílẹ̀-ède South Korea di ilú tó lámìlaka nígbẹ́yìn.

english: As the country grew prosperous, it was able to transition from an authoritarian government to a democratic government and has been able to reinvest in building its institutions.
yoruba: Bí orílẹ̀-èdè náà ṣe ń làmìlaka, ó rí ànfàní láti ṣe ìṣípòrọpò láti ìjọba apàṣẹ wàá sí ìjọba àwarawa wọ́n sì ti ni ànfàní láti dókówò nínú ki ́kọ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ rẹ̀.

english: And this has paid off tremendously.
yoruba: Èyí dẹ̀ ti mú èrè tó pọ̀ wá.

english: For instance, in 2018, South Korea's president was sentenced to 25 years in prison on corruption-related charges.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ní ọdún 2018, ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè South Korea gba ìdájọ́ ẹ̀wọn odún mẹ́ẹ̀dọ́gbọ̀n fún àwọn ẹ̀sùn tó níṣe pẹ̀lú ìwà-ìbàjẹ́.

english: This could never have happened decades ago when the country was poor and ruled by an authoritarian government.
yoruba: Èyí kì bá tí ṣẹlẹ̀ ní bíi ẹ̀wá ọdún sẹ́yìn nígbà tí orílẹ̀-èdè náà kúṣẹ̀ tó sì wà lábẹ́ ìjọba apàṣẹ wàá.

english: In fact, as we looked at most prosperous countries today, what we found was, they were able to reduce corruption as they became prosperous -- not before.
yoruba: Ní òótọ́, bí a ṣe ń wo ọpọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n làmìlaka jùlọ lónì, ohun tí a rí ni wí pé, wọ́n ní ànfàní láti mú àdínkù bá ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ń làmìlaka -- kìí ṣe ṣíwájú.

english: And so where does that leave us?
yoruba: Níbo wá ni ìyẹ́n fi wá sí?

english: I know it may sound like I'm saying we should just ignore corruption.
yoruba: Mo mọ̀ pé ó lè máa jọ bí ẹni pé mò ń sọ wí pé kí á fojú fo ìwà-ìbàjẹ́.

english: That's not what I'm saying at all.
yoruba: Kìí ṣe ǹkan tí mò ń sọ nìyẹn rárá.

english: What I'm suggesting, though, is that corruption, especially for most people in poor countries, is a work-around.
yoruba: Ǹkan tí mò ń dá lábàá, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé, ni wí pé ìwà-ìbàjẹ́, pàápàá jùlọ fún ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyànn ní àwòn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n kúṣẹ̀, ní wọ́n ń yà sílẹ̀.

english: It's a utility in a place where there are fewer better options to solve a problem.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ohun-ìlò kan ní ààyè níbi tójẹ́ wí pé ànfàní diẹ̀ ló wà láti yanjú ìṣòro.

english: Investing in innovations that make products much more affordable for many people not only attacks this scarcity but it creates a sustainable source of revenue for governments to reinvest into the economies to strengthen their institutions.
yoruba: Dídókówò nínu ìṣẹ̀da tó máa ń jẹ́ kí àwọn èròjà túbọ̀ rọjú fún ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn kò ní kojú ọ̀wọ́n yìí nìkan ṣùgbọ́n yóò pèse ọ̀nà ìpawó wọlé fún àwọn ìjọba láti dawó padà sínú ọrọ̀-ajé láti ró ilé-iṣẹ́ wọn lágbára.

english: This is the critical missing piece in the economic development puzzle that will ultimately help us reduce corruption.
yoruba: Èyí ni oríkèé pàtàkì tí ó sọnù nínu àyo ìdàgbàsókè ọrọ̀-ajé tí yóò ràn wá lọ́wọ́ láti mú àdínkù bá ìwà-ìbàjẹ́ nígbẹ́yìn.

english: You know, I lost hope in Nigeria when I was 16.
yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, mo sọ ìrètí nù nínu orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọ odún mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún.

english: And in some ways, the country has actually gotten worse.
yoruba: Ní àwọn ọ̀nà kànkan, orílẹ̀-èdè náà ti bàlùmọ̀ lóòtọ́.

english: In addition to widespread poverty and endemic corruption, Nigeria now actually deals with terrorist organizations like Boko Haram.
yoruba: Ní àfikún sí ìtànkálẹ̀ òṣì àti àjàkálẹ̀ ààrun ìwà-ìbàjẹ́, orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà ti ń kojú àwọn ẹgbẹ́ agbésúnmọ̀mí bíi Boko Haram báyìí.

english: But somehow, I am more hopeful about Nigeria today than I have ever been before.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣá, mo túbọ̀ ń ní ìrètí síi nípa orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà lónìí ju ti tẹ́lẹ̀ lọ.

english: When I see organizations investing in innovations that are creating jobs for people and making things affordable -- I mean organizations like Lifestores Pharmacy, making drugs and pharmaceuticals more affordable for people; or Metro Africa Xpress, tackling the scarcity of distribution and logistics for many small businesses; or Andela, creating economic opportunity for software developers -- I am optimistic about the future.
yoruba: Tí mó bá ń rí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tí wọ́ ń dókówò nínu ìṣẹ̀dá tó ń pèse iṣẹ́ fún àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n sì ń jẹ́ kí àwọn ǹkan ó rọjú -- mò ń sọ nípa àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ bíi ilé-ìtajà òògùn Lifestores, tó ń jẹ́ kí àwọn òògùn àti àwọn ohun èlò ìtọ́jú túbọ̀ rojú fún àwọn ènìyàn; tàbí Metro Africa Xpress, tó ń gbógun ti ọ̀wọ́n ìgbéká àti àwọn ohun-èlò fún àwọn òwò kékèké; tàbí Andela, tó ń pèsè ànfàni ọrọ̀-ajé fún àwọn tó ń pèse ohun-èlo kọ̀mpútà tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn -- Mo ní ìrètí nípa ọjọ́-iwájú.

english: I hope you will be, too.
yoruba: Mo lérò pé ìwọ náà yóò ní, bákan náà.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ seun.

english: How young Africans found a voice on Twitter
yoruba: Bí àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ṣe ń ṣe àwárí ohùn wọn lóri ìkàni Twitter.

english: It began with one question: If Africa was a bar, what would your country be drinking or doing?
yoruba: Ó bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìbéérè kan: tí ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bá jẹ́ ilé ọtí, kíni orílẹ̀-èdè rẹ yóò maa mu tàbí kíni yóò maa ṣe?

english: I kicked it off with a guess about South Africa, which wasn't exactly according to the rules because South Africa's not my country.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú èrò nípa orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, èyí tí kò tọ̀nà gẹ́gẹ́ bí òfin nítori orílẹ̀-ède South Africa kìí ṣe orílẹ̀-èdè mi.

english: But alluding to the country's continual attempts to build a postracial society after being ravaged for decades by apartheid, I tweeted, #ifafricawasabar South Africa would be drinking all kinds of alcohol and begging them to get along in its stomach.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n títọ́ka sí bí orílẹ̀-èdè náà ṣe ń gbìyànjú láti ṣẹ̀dá àwùjọ aìsíẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n ti kojú ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà fún aìmọye o

english: And then I waited.
yoruba: Mo bá dúró

english: And then I had that funny feeling where I wondered if I crossed the line.
yoruba: Ó bá ń ṣe mí bí ẹ̀rín níbi ti mo ti ń rò ó wí pé ṣé mi ò ti kọjá ẹnu àlà.

english: So, I sent out a few other tweets about my own country and a few other African countries I'm familiar with.
yoruba: Mo bá tún tẹ àwọn àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ míràn ránṣẹ́ nípa orílẹ̀-èdè tẹ̀mi gangan àti diẹ̀ nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè míràn ní ilẹ̀ Africa ti mo mọ̀ dijú.

english: And then I waited again, but this time I read through almost every tweet I had ever tweeted to convince myself, no, to remind myself that I'm really funny and that if nobody gets it, that's fine.
yoruba: Mo bá tún dúró, sùgbọ́n ní àsìkò yìí mo fẹ́rẹ̀ ka gbogbo àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ ti mo ti kọ rí láti fi dára mi lójú, rárá, láti rán ara mi létí wí pé aláwádà ni mí àti wí pé tí kò bá yé ẹnìkẹ́ni, ó dára.

english: But luckily, I didn't have to do that for very long.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n oríire mi, mi ò ní láti ṣe èyí fún ìgbà pípẹ́.

english: Very soon, people were participating.
yoruba: Láìpẹ́, àwọn ènìyàn ti ń kópa.

english: In fact, by the end of that week in July, the hashtag #ifafricawasabar would have garnered around 60,000 tweets, lit up the continent and made its way to publications all over the world.
yoruba: Lóòtọ́, nígbà tí yóò fi di ìparí ọ̀sẹ̀ yẹn nínú oṣù Agẹmọ, ìkàni #tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí ti ní àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ tó ń lọ bi ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́ta, ó tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ yíká ẹkùn náà ó sì ti di títẹ̀ jáde káàkiri àgbáyé.

english: People were using the hashtag to do many different things.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn ń lo ìkànì náà láti ṣe oríṣiríṣi ǹkan.

english: To poke fun at their stereotypes: [#IfAfricaWasABar Nigeria would be outside explaining that he will pay the entrance fee, all he needs is the bouncer's account details.
yoruba: Láti nàka sí ìgbàgbọ wọn: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà yóò wà níta tí yóò ma ṣàlàyé wí pé òhun yóò san owó ìwọlé, gbogbo ohun tó nílò ni àlàyé nípa ilé-ìfowopamọ́ ẹ̀ṣọ́ tó wà lẹ́nu ọ̀nà.

english: To criticize government spending: [#ifafricawasabar South Africa would be ordering bottles it can't pronounce running a tab it won't be able to pay]
yoruba: Láti tako ìnáwó ìjọba: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède South Africa yóò ma bèrè fún àwọn ìgò tí kò léè pè ti yóó sì máa jẹ gbèsè tí kò ní lè san]

english: To make light of geopolitical tensions: [#IfAfricaWasABar South Sudan would be the new guy with serious anger management issues.
yoruba: Láti sọ ìbẹ̀rùbojo ọrọ̀-ajé agbègbè di fúfúyẹ́: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède South Sudan yóò jẹ́ ọkùnrin tuntun náà tó ní ìṣòro ìṣàmójú tó ìbínú ẹni.

english: To remind us that even in Africa there are some countries we don't know exist: [#IfAfricaWasABar Lesotho would be that person who nobody really knows but is always in the pictures.
yoruba: Láti rán wa léti pé kódà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè kan ń bẹ ti a kò mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n wà: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède Lesotho yóò jẹ́ ẹni náà tí ẹnikẹ́ni ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ̀ ṣùgbọ́n tó máa ń wà nínú àwòrán ní gbogbo ìgbà.

english: And also to make fun of the countries that don't think that they're in Africa: [#IfAfricaWasABar Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco be like "What the hell are we doing here?
yoruba: Bákan náà ni láti fi àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọn ò lérò wí pé ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni àwọ́n wà ṣe yẹ̀yẹ́: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède Egypt, Libya, Tunisia, Algeria, àti Morocco máa wò ó wí pé "kíni à ń ṣe níbí?

english: And to note the countries that had made a big turnaround: [#ifAfricawasabar Rwanda would be that girl that comes with no money and no transport but leaves drunk, happy and rich]
yoruba: Àti láti mọ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí àyípadà ńlá ti débá: [#tíIlẹ̀Adúláwọ̀bájẹ́iléọtí orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda yóò jẹ́ ọmọbìnrin yẹn tó wá láìní owó lọ́wọ́ láìní owó ọkọ̀ sùgbọ́n tí ó kúrò lẹ́ni tó ti mutí yó, tó ń dunú tó sì dolówó].

english: But most importantly, people were using the hashtag to connect.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní pátàkì jùlọ, àwọn ènìyàn ń lo ìkànì náà láti sopọ̀.

english: People were connecting over their Africanness.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn ń sopọ̀ nípa ìjẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: So for one week in July, Twitter became a real African bar.
yoruba: Fún òsẹ̀ kan nínu oṣù Agẹmọ, ìkàni Twitter di ilé-ọtí ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lóòtọ́.

english: And I was really thrilled, mainly because I realized that Pan-Africanism could work, that we had before us, between us, at our fingertips a platform that just needed a small spark to light in us a hunger for each other.
yoruba: Imú mi sì dùn, nítorí mo ríi wí pé ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lè ṣiṣẹ́, tó wà níwájúu wa, láàrín wa, ní àrọ́wọ́tó wa tó kọ̀ nílò ògúná kékeré láti tan iná ìjẹ̀ran ara wa.

english: My name is Siyanda Mohutsiwa, I'm 22 years old and I am Pan-Africanist by birth.
yoruba: Orúkọ mi ni Siyanda Mohutsiwa, mo jẹ́ ọmọdún méjì-lé-lógún mo sì jẹ́ olólùfẹ́ ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìbí.

english: Now, I say I'm Pan-Africanist by birth because my parents are from two different African countries.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, mó ní mo jẹ́ olólùfẹ́ ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìbí nítorí wí pé àwọn òbí mi wá láti orílẹ̀-èdè méjì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: My father's from a country called Botswana in southern Africa.
yoruba: Bàbá mi jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n ń pè ní Botswana ní gúúsù ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: It's only slightly bigger than Germany.
yoruba: Díẹ̀ ló fi tóbi ju orílẹ̀-ède Germany lọ.

english: This year we celebrate our 50th year of stable democracy.
yoruba: Ní ọdún yìí a ṣe ayẹyẹ àdọ́ta ọdún ìdúró ṣinṣin ọmìnira wa.

english: And it has some very progressive social policies.
yoruba: Ó sì ní àwọn ìpinnu ìtẹ̀síẃjú àwùjọ gidi.

english: My mother's country is the Kingdom of Swaziland.
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè ìyá mi ni ìlu-ọba Swaziland.

english: It's a very, very small country, also in southern Africa.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè tó kéré púpọ̀, tí ohun náà wà ní gúúsù ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: It is Africa's last complete monarchy.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ilú tó gbẹ́yìn nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí ìṣèlú lábẹ́ ọba rẹ̀ ṣì pé.

english: So it's been ruled by a king and a royal family in line with their tradition, for a very long time.
yoruba: Ó ti wà lábẹ́ ìdarí ọba àti ìdílé ọba kan ní ìbámu pẹ̀lú àṣa wọn, fún ìgbà pípẹ́.

english: On paper, these countries seem very different.
yoruba: Lórí ìwé, àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè wọ̀nyí lè dàbi ẹní yátọ̀ gidi gan.

english: And when I was a kid, I could see the difference.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọdé, mo máa ń rí ìyàtọ̀ náà.

english: It rained a lot in one country, it didn't rain quite as much in the other.
yoruba: Òjó máa ń rọ̀ púpọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-èdè kan, kìí rọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ìkejì.

english: But outside of that, I didn't really realize why it mattered that my parents were from two different places.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n yàtọ̀ sí èyí, mi ò tilẹ̀ mọ̀ ìdi tó fi pọn dandan pé àwọn òbí mi wá láti àyè méjì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

english: But it would go on to have a very peculiar effect on me.
yoruba: Sùgbọ́n yóò padà nípa ọ̀tọ̀ lára mi.

english: You see, I was born in one country and raised in the other.
yoruba: Ṣé ẹ ríi, wọ́n bími ní orílẹ̀-èdè kan wọ́n sì rè mí ní ìkejì.

english: When we moved to Botswana, I was a toddler who spoke fluent SiSwati and nothing else.
yoruba: Nígbà tí a kó lọ sí orílẹ̀-ède Botswana, mo jẹ́ ọmọ òpónlo tó ń sọ SiSwati dijú láìsí ǹkan mìíràn.

english: So I was being introduced to my new home, my new cultural identity, as a complete outsider, incapable of comprehending anything that was being said to me by the family and country whose traditions I was meant to move forward.
yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n fi ojú mi mọ ilé tuntun, àsà abínibí mi tuntun, gẹ́gẹ́ bí aráàta pátápátá, tí ò ní ìkápá láti ní òye ǹkan tí àwọn ẹbí mi ń sọfún mi àti orílẹ̀-èdè tó yẹ kí n gbé àṣa rẹ̀ lárugẹ.

english: But very soon, I would shed SiSwati.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n láìpẹ́, màá sọ SiSwati nù.

english: And when I would go back to Swaziland, I would be constantly confronted by how very non-Swazi I was becoming.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo bá ma padà lọ sí orílẹ̀-ède Swaziland, màá máa ní ìdojúkọ lemọ́lemọ́ pẹ̀lú bí mo ti ṣe ń di eni tí kìí ṣe ọmọ Swazi mọ́.

english: Add to that my entry into Africa's private school system, whose entire purpose is to beat the Africanness out of you, and I would have a very peculiar adolescence.
yoruba: Sí ìyẹn ìwọlé mi sínú èto ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ aládàni ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, tó jẹ́ pé gbogbo èro tiwọn ni láti gbọn ìjẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ dànù kúrò láraà rẹ, tí màá sì ní ìjẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ tó yátọ̀.

english: But I think that my interest in ideas of identity was born here, in the strange intersection of belonging to two places at once but not really belonging to either one very well and belonging to this vast space in between and around simultaneously.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo rò wí pé ìfẹ́ mi nínú èro ìdánimọ̀ ni wọ́n bí síbí, pẹ̀lú ìkọlura àjòjì pé mo jẹ́ ọmọ ìlú méjì lẹ́ẹ̀kan náà ṣùgbọ́n tí mi ò fi tara-tara jẹ́ ti ìkankan nínú wọn dáadáa ti mo sì jẹ́ ti àyè to fẹ̀ yíì láàrín àti yíká rẹ̀ lẹ́ẹ̀kan náà.

english: I became obsessed with the idea of a shared African identity.
yoruba: Mo di ẹni tó ń nífẹ̀ẹ́ sí èrò ìdánimò ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àjọni.

english: Since then, I have continued to read about politics and geography and identity and what all those things mean.
yoruba: Láti ìgbà náà, mo ti tẹ̀síwájú láti máa kà nípa òṣèlú àti ẹ̀kọ́ nípa ayé àti ìdánimọ̀ àti ǹkan ti àwọn wọ̀nyí túmọ̀ sí.

english: I've also held on to a deep curiosity about African philosophies.
yoruba: Mo tún ti ni òye tó jinlẹ̀ nípa ìmọ̀ ìjìnlẹ̀-èrò ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: When I began to read, I gravitated towards the works of black intellectuals like Steve Biko and Frantz Fanon, who tackled complex ideas like decolonization and black consciousness.
yoruba: Nígbà ti mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní kàwé, mo sún mọ́ iṣẹ́ àwọn aláwọ̀-dúdú tó láròjinlẹ̀ bi Steve Biko àti Frantz Fanon, tó tako àwọn èrò àmúdijú bíi aìmúnisìn àti ìmọ aláwọ̀ dúdú.

english: And when I thought, at 14, that I had digested these grand ideas, I moved on to the speeches of iconic African statesmen like Burkina Faso's Thomas Sankara and Congo's Patrice Lumumba.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo rò ó, ní ọmọdún mẹ́rìnlá, pé mo ti mọ gbogbo èrò tó gbòòrò wọ̀nyí, mo tẹ̀síwájú sí ọ̀rọ̀ àwọn àgbà akọni ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bíi Thomas Sankara ti orílẹ̀-ède Burkina Faso àti Patrice Lumumba ti orílẹ̀-ède Congo.

english: I read every piece of African fiction that I could get my hands on.
yoruba: Mo ka gbogbo ìtàn-àròsọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí mo lè fi ọwọ́ bà.

english: So when Twitter came, I hopped on with the enthusiasm of a teenage girl whose friends are super, super bored of hearing about all this random stuff.
yoruba: Nítorí náà nígbà ti ìkàni Twitter dé, mo fò sókè pẹ̀lú ìdùnú ọmọbìnrin tó wà lábẹ́ ogún ọdún tó ti sú àwọn ọ̀rẹ rẹ̀ láti máa gbọ́ nípa àwọn ǹkan tí kò ní ètò wọ̀nyí.

english: The year was 2011 and all over southern Africa and the whole continent, affordable data packages for smartphones and Internet surfing became much easier to get.
yoruba: 2011 ni ọdún náà yíká gbogbo gúúsù ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti gbogbo ẹkùn náà, àwọn èto dátà tí kò gani lára fún ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ ayárabí àṣá àti lílọ sórí ìkàni ayélukára di ìrọ̀rùn síi láti rí.

english: So my generation, we were sending messages to each other on this platform that just needed 140 characters and a little bit of creativity.
yoruba: Ìran tèmi, à ń fi àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ ránṣẹ́ sí ara wa lóri ìkànì yìí tó kọ̀ nílò ogóje lẹ́tà àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá diẹ̀.

english: On long commutes to work, in lectures that some of us should have been paying attention to, on our lunch breaks, we would communicate as much as we could about the everyday realities of being young and African.
yoruba: Ní ìrìnàjò tó jìn lọ síbi iṣẹ́, ní àwọn ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tó yẹ kí àwọn kan nínú wa máa fi ọkàn sí, lásìko ìjáde oúnjẹ ọ̀sán wa, a máa ń sọ̀rọ̀ ní ọ̀pọ̀ tí a lè sọ nípa ìbáyému ojoojúmọ́ nípa ìjẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ àti ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: But of course, this luxury was not available to everybody.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, ọrọ̀ yìí ò sí fún gbogbo ènìyàn.

english: So this meant that if you were a teenage girl in Botswana and you wanted to have fun on the Internet, one, you had to tweet in English.
yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wí pé tí o bá jẹ́ ọmọbìnrin lábẹ́ ogún ọdún ní orílẹ̀-ède Botswana tí o sì fẹ́ ṣe fàájì lórí ìkàni ayélukára, àkọ́kọ́, o ní láti tẹ àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ ní ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: Two, you had to follow more than just the three other people you knew online.
yoruba: Ẹ̀kejì, o ní láti tẹ̀lé jú àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́ta mìíràn tí o mọ̀ lórí ìkàni ayélukára lọ.

english: You had to follow South Africans, Zimbabweans, Ghanaians, Nigerians.
yoruba: O ní láti tẹ̀lé àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, Zimbabawe, Ghana, Nigeria.

english: And suddenly, your whole world opened up.
yoruba: Lójijì, gbogbo ìgbésíayé rẹ yóò ṣí sílẹ̀.

english: And my whole world did open up.
yoruba: Gbogbo ìgbésíayé mi dẹ̀ ṣí sílẹ̀ lóòtọ́.

english: I followed vibrant Africans who were travelling around the continent, taking pictures of themselves and posting them under the hashtag #myafrica.
yoruba: Mo tẹ̀lé àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí wọ́n gbónu tí wọ́n ń rín ìrìnàjò káàkiri ẹkùn náà, tí wọ́n ń ya àwòrán ara wọn tí wọ́n sì ń fi ránṣẹ ́lábẹ́ ìkàni #ilẹ̀Adúláwọ̀mi.

english: Because at that time, if you were to search Africa on Twitter or on Google or any kind of social media, you would think that the entire continent was just pictures of animals and white guys drinking cocktails in hotel resorts.
yoruba: Torí ní àsìkò náà, tí o bá fẹ́ wá ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lóri ìkani Twitter tàbi lóri Google tàbí èyíkéyí ìkànì ìbánidọ́rẹ̀, wàá lérò wí pé gbogbo ẹkùn náà kọ̀ jẹ́ àwòran ẹranko àti àwọn aláwọ̀-funfun tí wọ́n ń muti ní àwọn ilé ìtura ìgbafẹ́ ni.

english: But Africans were using this platform to take some kind of ownership of the tourism sectors.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ń lo ìkànì yìí láti kéde ìní àwọn ẹ̀ka ìrìn-àjo afẹ́.

english: It was Africans taking selfies on the beaches of Nigeria.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni wọ́n ń ya àwòrán ní etí òkun orílẹ̀-ède Nàìjíríà .

english: It was Africans in cocktail bars in Nairobi.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni wọ́n wà ní àwọn ilé-ọtí ni orílẹ̀-ède Nairobi.

english: And these were the same Africans that I began to meet in my own travels around the continent.
yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí kan náà ni àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí pàdé nínú ìrìnàjo tèmi gaan yíká ẹkùn náà.

english: We would discuss African literature, politics, economic policy.
yoruba: A máa ń jírórò nípa lítiréṣọ̀ ilè Adúláwọ̀, òṣèlú, ìpinnu ọrọ̀-ajé

english: But almost invariably, every single time, we would end up discussing Twitter.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n láìní yípada, ní àsìkò kànkan, a máa ń padà sọ nípa Twitter.

english: And that's when I realized what this was.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni mo mọ ohun tí èyí jẹ́.

english: We were standing in the middle of something amazing, because for the first time ever young Africans could discuss the future of our continent in real time, without the restriction of borders, finances and watchful governments.
yoruba: A dúró láàrín ǹkankan tó yanilẹ́nu, nítorí fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lè jírórò nípa ọjọ́-iwájú ẹkùn wọn lásíkò, láìsí ìdíwọ́ ibodè, owó àti ìjọba aṣọ́ni.

english: Because the little known truth is many Africans know a lot less about other African countries than some Westerners might know about Africa as a whole.
yoruba: Nítorí òótọ́ díè tí a mọ̀ ni wí pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ò ní ìmọ̀ púpọ̀ nípa àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Adúláwọ̀ tókù ju bí àwọn aláwọ̀ funfun ṣe lè mọ̀ nípa ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lápapọ̀.

english: This is by accident, but sometimes, it's by design.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ àṣìṣe, ṣùgbọ́n nígbà míràn, ó lè jẹ́ nípa àtò.

english: For example, in apartheid South Africa, black South Africans were constantly being bombarded with this message that any country ruled by black people was destined for failure.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ní àsìko ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà ní orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, àwọn aláwọ̀-dúdú ní South Africa ni wọ́n ń ránṣẹ́ sí ní gbogbo ìgbà pé orílẹ̀-èdè ti aláwọ̀-dúdú bá ń darí ti yan àyànmọ́ ìjakulẹ̀.

english: And this was done to convince them that they were much better off under crushing white rule than they were living in a black and free nation.
yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe èyí láti fi dáwọn lójú wí pé ìgbeayé àwọ́n dára lábẹ́ òòrìn ìjọba aláwọ̀-funfun ju bí àwọ́n ṣe ń gbé ní orílẹ̀-ède aláwọ̀-dúdú àti olómìnira.

english: Add to that Africa's colonial, archaic education system, which has been unthinkingly carried over from the 1920s -- and at the age of 15, I could name all the various causes of the wars that had happened in Europe in the past 200 years, but I couldn't name the president of my neighboring country.
yoruba: Ní àfikún sí ìyẹn ètò ẹ̀kọ ìjọba amúnisìn ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ti darúgbó, tí wọ́n ti gbé kọjá láìbá ìrònú mu láti àsìko ọdún 1920 -- nígbàtí mo wà ní ọmọ ọdún mẹ́ẹ̀dógún, mo lè dárúkọ gbogbo okùnfa àwọn ogun tí ó ti wáyé nílẹ̀ Yúróòpù láti ní igba odún sẹyìn, ṣùgbọ́n mi ò lè dárúkọ olórí orílẹ̀-èdè tó súmọ mi.

english: And to me, this doesn't make any sense because whether we like it or not, the fates of African people are deeply intertwined.
yoruba: Sí èmi, èyí ò bá ìrònú mu nítorí boyá a fẹ́ tàbí a kọ̀, ìrètí àwọn ènìyan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ wọnú ara wọn.

english: When disaster hits, when turmoil hits, we share the consequences.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ọ̀fọ́ bá ṣẹ̀, tí wàhálà bá ṣẹlẹ̀, ajọ máa ń pín ìpadàbọ rẹ̀ ni.

english: When Burundians flee political turmoil, they go to us, to other African countries.
yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn ara ìlu Burundi sá fún wàhálà òṣèlú, wọ́n wá báwa, sí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tókù nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: Africa has six of the world's largest refugee centers.
yoruba: Ilè Adúláwọ̀ ní mẹ́fà nínú àwọn ààyè àwọn atìpó tó tóbi jù lágbàyé.

english: What was once a Burundian problem becomes an African problem.
yoruba: Ǹkan tó jẹ́ ìṣòro ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède Burundi nígbà kan ti di ìṣòro ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: So to me, there are no Sudanese problems or South African problems or Kenyan problems, only African problems because eventually, we share the turmoil.
yoruba: Sí èmi, kò sí ǹkan tó ń jẹ́ ìṣòro orílẹ̀-ède sudan tàbí orílẹ̀-ède South Africa tàbí ìṣòro orílẹ̀-ède kenya, ìṣòro ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nìkan ni nítorí nígbẹ́yìn, a jọ́ ń pín ìṣòro náà ni.

english: So if we share the problems, why aren't we doing a better job of sharing the successes?
yoruba: Nítorí náà tí a bá jọ pín àwọn ìṣòro náà, kí ló dé tí a ò ṣiṣẹ́ dáadáa láti pín àwọn àṣeyọrí náà?

english: How can we do that?
yoruba: Báwo la ṣe lè ṣe ìyẹn?

english: Well, in the long term, we can shoot towards increasing inter-African trade, removing borders and putting pressure on leaders to fulfill regional agreements they've already signed.
yoruba: Ó daa, ní àsìkò ọjọ́ iwájú, a lè pinnu nípa ṣíṣe àfikún sí òwò láàrin ilè Adúláwọ̀, pẹ̀lú yíyọ àwọn ibodè kúrò àti gbígbé ẹrù ru àwọn adarí wa láti ṣe ìmúṣẹ àwọn àdéhùn agbègbè tí wọ́n ti buwọ́ lù.

english: But I think that the biggest way for Africa to share its successes is to foster something I like to call social Pan-Africanism.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo rò wí pé onà tó tóbi jù fún ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ láti pín àṣeyọrí rẹ̀ ni láti sàmójútó ǹkan tí mo fẹ́ràn láti pè ní ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: Now, political Pan-Africanism already exists, so I'm not inventing anything totally new here.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, òṣèlú ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwò ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀, nítorí náà mi ò ṣe àgbélẹ̀rọ ǹkan tuntun níbí.

english: But political Pan-Africanism is usually the African unity of the political elite.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n òṣèlú ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ máa ń sábà jẹ́ ìṣọ̀kan àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ nínú òṣèlú.

english: And who does that benefit?
yoruba: Ta ni ìyẹn wá ń se ànfàní fún?

english: Well, African leaders, almost exclusively.
yoruba: Ó dáa, àwọn adarí nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ jẹ́ ní àdáyanrí.

english: No, what I'm talking about is the Pan-Africanism of the ordinary African.
yoruba: Rárá, ohun tí mò ń sọ nípa rẹ̀ ni ìṣọ̀kan ilẹ̀ Africa àwọn ènìyan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: Young Africans like me, we are bursting with creative energy, with innovative ideas.
yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀ b́ii tèmi, tí a kún fún agbára ọgbọ́n àtinúdá, pẹ̀lú èro ìṣẹ̀dá.

english: But with bad governance and shaky institutions, all of this potential could go to waste.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lu ijọba tí ò da àti orílẹ̀-èdè tó ń ṣòjòjò, gbogbo èbùn yìí lè má wùlo.

english: On a continent where more than a handful of leaders have been in power longer than the majority of the populations has been alive, we are in desperate need of something new, something that works.
yoruba: Ní ẹkùn tí àwọn adarí diẹ̀ ti wà ní ìjọba ju iye ọdún tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ará ìlú ti lò láyé, a nílò ǹkan tuntun lọ́nàkọnà, ǹkan tí yóò ṣiṣẹ́.

english: And I think that thing is social Pan-Africanism.
yoruba: Mo dẹ̀ rò ó wí pé ǹkan náà ni ìṣọ̀kan àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: My dream is that young Africans stop allowing borders and circumstance to suffocate our innovation.
yoruba: Àlá mi ni pé kí àwọn ọ̀dọ́ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ kọ̀ láti máa jẹ́ kí ibodè àti àwọn ǹkan tó lè dóru mú ìṣẹ̀da wa.

english: My dream is that when a young African comes up with something brilliant, they don't say, "Well, this wouldn't work in my country," and then give up.
yoruba: Àlá mi ni pé tí ọ̀dọ́ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bá wá pẹ̀lú ǹkan tó mọ́yán lórí, wọn ò ní sọ wí pé, eléyìí kò ní ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ilú mi, " kí wọ́n wá jáwọ́.

english: My dream is that young Africans begin to realize that the entire continent is our canvas, is our home.
yoruba: Àlá mi ni pé àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní mọ̀ pé gbogbo ẹkùn náà ni ibùsun wa, ni ilée wa.

english: Using the Internet, we can begin to think collaboratively, we can begin to innovate together.
yoruba: Lílo ìkàni ayélukára, a lè bẹ̀rè síní ronú papọ̀, a lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ṣẹ̀da ohun-ọ̀tun lápapọ̀.

english: In Africa, we say, "If you want to go fast, you go alone, but if you want to go far, you go together.
yoruba: Nílẹ̀ adúláwọ̀, a máa ń sọ pé, "tí ó bá fẹ́ yára lọ, o lè dá nìkan lọ, ṣùgbọ́n tí o bá fẹ́ rìn jìnà, ẹ kọ́wọ̀ọ́ rìn.

english: And I believe that social Pan-Africanism is how we can go far together.
yoruba: Mo dẹ̀ nígbàgbọ́ wí pé ìṣọ̀kan àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni ọ̀nà tí a lè fi jọ rìn jìnà lápapọ̀.

english: And this is already happening.
yoruba: Èyí dẹ̀ ti ń ṣẹlẹ̀.

english: Access to these online networks has given young Africans something we've always had to violently take: a voice.
yoruba: Ànfàni sí àwọn ìkànì ayélukára wọ̀nyí ti fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní ǹkan tí a ti máa ń fi rògbòdìyàn gbà.

english: We now have a platform.
yoruba: A ti ní ìkànì kan.

english: Before now, if you wanted to be heard by your possibly tyrannical government, you were pushed to protest, suffer the consequences and have your fingers crossed that some Western paper somewhere might make someone care.
yoruba: Ṣíwájú àkókò yìí, tí o bá fẹ́ di gbígbọ́ lọ́dọ̀ ìjọba apàṣẹ wàá rẹ, wọ́n ó tìẹ́ láti ṣe ìfẹ̀hónú hàn, láti faragbá ìpadàbọ rẹ̀ tí wàá sìkáwọ́ọ̀ rẹ rọ̀ pé àwọn ìwé-ìròyìn aláwọ̀ funfun níbìkan lè jẹ́ kí ẹnìkan ó nífẹ̀ sí i.

english: But now we have opportunities to back each other up in ways we never could before.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nísinyìí a ní àwọn ànfàní láti gberawa lẹ́yìn ní àwọn ọ̀nà tí a kò lè ṣe tẹ́lẹ̀.

english: We support South African students who are marching against ridiculously high tertiary fees.
yoruba: A ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ orílẹ̀-ède South Africa tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìwọ́de tako owó gegere ilé-ìwé gíga.

english: We support Zimbabwean women who are marching to parliament.
yoruba: A ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn obìnrin ní orílẹ̀-ède Zimbabwe tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìwọ́de lọ sí ilé aṣòfin.

english: We support Angolan journalists who are being illegally detained.
yoruba: A ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn akọ̀ròyin orílẹ̀-ède Angólà tí wọ́n ń mú sí àtìmọ́lé lọ́nà tí ò bófin mu.

english: For the first time ever, African pain and African aspiration has the ability to be witnessed by those who can empathize with it the most: other Africans.
yoruba: Fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́, ẹ̀dun ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àfojúsùn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní ànfàní láti di rírí fún àwọn tí wọ́n lẹ̀ kẹ́dùn pẹ̀lú rẹ̀ jù: àwọn òwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Ad́láwọ̀ tókù.

english: I believe that with a social Pan-Africanist thinking and using the Internet as a tool, we can begin to rescue each other, and ultimately, to rescue ourselves.
yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ pé pẹ̀lú ìrònú nípa ìṣọ̀kan àwùjọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti ìkàni ayélukára gẹ́gẹ́ bi irinṣẹ́, a lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní gba ara wa sílẹ̀, nígbẹ́yìn, láti gbarawa sílẹ̀.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ń ran àwọn ìyá lọ́wọ́ láti jagun ààrun kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: I want you to take a trip with me.
yoruba: Mo fẹ́ kí ẹ rin ìrìnàjò kan pèlú mi.

english: Picture yourself driving down a small road in Africa, and as you drive along, you look off to the side, and this is what you see: you see a field of graves.
yoruba: Ẹ àwòran ara yín bí ẹni tó ń wakọ̀ ní ọnà tóóró kan nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, bí o ṣe ń wakọ̀ lọ, o gbojú sí ẹ̀gbẹ́, ǹkan tí o sì rí rèé: o rí àyè tí wọ́n sìnkú sí.

english: And you stop, and you get out of your car and you take a picture.
yoruba: Ẹ wá dúró, o bọ́síta nínú ọkọ̀ yín ẹ dẹ̀ ya àwòrán kan.

english: And you go into the town, and you inquire, "What's going on here? and people are initially reluctant to tell you.
yoruba: Ẹ wá wọ àdúgbò náà lọ, ẹ wá ń bèrè, "kí ló ń ṣẹlẹ̀ níbí? " ní àkọ́kọ́ àwọn ẹnìyan lọ́ra láti sọ fún yín.

english: And then someone says, "These are the recent AIDS deaths in our community.
yoruba: Nigbà náà ni ẹnìkan sọ wí pé, "Àwọn wọ̀nyí ni àwọn ikú kòkòro apa sójà ara ní àwùjọ wa láìpẹ́ yìí.

english: HIV isn't like other medical conditions; it's stigmatizing.
yoruba: " Kòkòro apa sójà ara ò dàbí àwọn aìsàn tókù; ó máa ń fa ìdẹ́yẹsí.

english: People are reluctant to talk about it -- there's a fear associated with it.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyán máa ń lọ́ra láti sọ̀rọ̀ nípa rẹ̀ -- ìbẹ̀rù kan rọ̀ mọ.

english: And I'm going to talk about HIV today, about the deaths, about the stigma.
yoruba: Màá sọ nípa kòkòro apa sójà ara lónì, nípa ikú, nípa ìdẹ́yẹsí.

english: It's a medical story, but more than that, it's a social story.
yoruba: Ìtan ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn ni, ṣùgbọ́n jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, ìtàn àwùjọ ni.

english: This map depicts the global distribution of HIV.
yoruba: Àwòrán orílẹ̀-èdè yìí fi ìpín kòkòro apa sójà ara ní ilẹ̀ àgbáyé hàn.

english: And as you can see, Africa has a disproportionate share of the infection.
yoruba: Bí ẹ ṣe rí i, Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ló ní ìpín àkóràn tó pọ̀jù.

english: There are 33 million people living with HIV in the world today.
yoruba: Mílíọ́nù mẹ́tà-lé-lọ́gbọ̀n (33) àwọn ènìyàn ni wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lú kòkòro apa sójà ara lágbáyé lónì.

english: Of these, two-thirds, 22 million are living in sub-Saharan Africa.
yoruba: Nínú àwọn wọ̀nyí, ìdá méjì nínú mẹ́ta, mílíọ́nù méjì-lé-lógún ni wọ́n ń gbé ní ìwọ̀-oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: There are 1.4 million pregnant women in low- and middle-income countries living with HIV and of these, 90 percent are in sub-Saharan Africa.
yoruba: Mílíọ́nù kan lé ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà erínwó ni àwọn aláboyún ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ìpawó-wọlé wọn kére tàbí tó wà lágbede méjì tí wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lu kòkòro apa sójà ara nínú àwọn wọ̀nyí, ìdá àdọ́rùn wà ní iwọ̀-oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: We talk about things in relative terms.
yoruba: A máa ń sọ́rọ̀ nípa ǹkan pẹ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀-ìperí tó jọra wọn.

english: And I'm going to talk about annual pregnancies and HIV-positive mothers.
yoruba: Màá sọ̀rọ̀ nípa oyún ọdọọdún àti àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ti ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: The United States -- a large country -- each year, 7,000 mothers with HIV who give birth to a child.
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-ède Amẹ́ríkà -- orílẹ̀-èdè tó tóbi -- lọ́dọọdún, ẹgbẹ̀rún méje (7,000) àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara ni wọ́n bímọ.

english: But you go to Rwanda -- a very small country -- 8,000 mothers with HIV who are pregnant.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ẹ̀yin ẹ lọ sí orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda -- orílẹ̀-èdè tó kéré jọjọ -- ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́jọ (8,000) àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara tí wọ́n lóyún.

english: And then you go to Baragwanath Hospital, outside of Johannesburg in South Africa, and 8,000 HIV-positive pregnant women giving birth -- a hospital the same as a country.
yoruba: Kí ẹ wá lọ sí ilé-ìwòsan Baragwanath, ní ìta Johannesburg ní orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, àti ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́jọ (8,000) àwọn aláboyún tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara tí wọ́n ń bímọ -- ilé-ìwòsàn kan tó ṣe dèèdé pẹ̀lu orílẹ̀-èdè kan.

english: And to realize that this is just the tip of an iceberg that when you compare everything here to South Africa, it just pales, because in South Africa, each year 300,000 mothers with HIV give birth to children.
yoruba: Láti wá mọ̀ wí pé a ṣẹ̀ ń mẹ́yẹ bọ̀ lápò ni pé tí ẹ bá ṣàfiwée gbogbo ǹkan níbí sí orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, ó kọ̀ funfun ni, nítorí ní orílẹ̀-ède South Africa, ní ọdọọdún ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọ̀rìn-dín-nírinwó (300,000) àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara ni wọ́n bímọ.

english: So we talk about PMTCT, and we refer to PMTCT, prevention of mother to child transmission.
yoruba: A sọ̀rọ̀ nípa PMTCT, a sì máa ń tọ́ka sí PMTCT, ìdèna àkóràn ìyá sí ọmọ.

english: I think there's an assumption amongst most people in the public that if a mother is HIV-positive, she's going to infect her child.
yoruba: Mo rò wí pé èrò kan wà láàrín ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn láwùjọ pé tí ìyá bá ní kòkòro apa sójà ara, ó máa kó o ran ọmọ rẹ̀.

english: The reality is really, very different.
yoruba: Òtítọ́ náà yátọ̀ gidi gan.

english: In resource-rich countries, with all the tests and treatment we currently have, less than two percent of babies are born HIV-positive -- 98 percent of babies are born HIV-negative.
yoruba: Ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n ní ohun àlùmọ́nì lọ́pọ̀, pẹ̀lú gbogbo àyẹ̀wò àti ìtọ́jú tí a ní, ó dín ní ìdá méjì àwọn ìkókó tí wọ́n bí pẹ̀lú kòkòro apa sójà ara -- ìdá méjì-dín-lọ́gọ́rùn àwọn ìkókó ni wọn kò ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: And yet, the reality in resource-poor countries, in the absence of tests and treatment, 40 percent -- 40 percent of children are infected -- 40 percent versus two percent -- an enormous difference.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, òtítọ́ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọn kò ní ohun-èlò, tí kò sí àyèwò àti ìtọ́jú, ìda ogójì -- ìda ogójì àwọn ọmọ ni wọ́n ní i -- ìda ogójì kojúu ìdá méjì – ìyàtọ̀ tó pọ̀ gidi gan.

english: So these programs -- and I'm going to refer to PMTCT though my talk -- these prevention programs, simply, they're the tests and the drugs that we give to mothers to prevent them from infecting their babies, and also the medicines we give to mothers to keep them healthy and alive to raise their children.
yoruba: Àwọn ètò yìí -- màá tọ́ka sí PMTCT bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé ìjírórò mi – àwọn ètò ìdènà wọ̀nyí, ní ṣókí, àwọn ni àwọn àyẹ̀wò àti àwọn òògùn tí à ń fún àwọn ìyá láti dèna àkóràn àwọn ọmọ wọn, bákan náà àwọn òògùn tí à ń fún àwọn ìyá láti jẹ́ kí ara wọ́n le kí wọ́n lè wà láyé láti re àwọn ọmọ wọn.

english: So it's the test a mother gets when she comes in.
yoruba: Àyẹ̀wò náà ni ìyá ń gbà nígbà tó bá wọlé wá.

english: It's the drugs she receives to protect the baby that's inside the uterus and during delivery.
yoruba: Àwọn ògùn tí ó gbà láti dáábò bo ọmọ tó wà ní ilé-ọmọ àti lásíkò ìrọbí.

english: It's the guidance she gets around infant feeding and safer sex.
yoruba: Àwọn ìtọ́sọ́nà tó ń gbà nípa ìfọ́mọlọ́mú àti ìbálópọ̀ aláìléwu.

english: It's an entire package of services, and it works.
yoruba: Àkójọpọ̀ gbogbo iṣẹ́ ni, ó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́.

english: So in the United States, since the advent of treatment in the middle of the 1990s, there's been an 80-percent decline in the number of HIV-infected children.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀ ède Amẹ́ríkà, láti ìgbà tí ìtọ́jú ti dé láàrín àsìko ọdún 1990, àdínkù tó tó ìdá ọgọ́rin ti dé bá iye àwọn ọmọ tó ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: Less than 100 babies are born with HIV each year in the United States and yet, still, over 400,000 children are born every year in the world today with HIV.
yoruba: Àwọn ìkókó tó dín ní ọgọ́rùn ni wọ́n ń bí pẹ̀lu kòkòro apa sójà ara lọ́dọọdún ní orílẹ̀-ède Amẹ́ríkà síbẹ̀, bákan náà, ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà erínwó lé ọmọ ni wọ́n ń bí lọ́dọọdún lágbàyé lónì tó ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: What does that mean?
yoruba: Kíni ìyẹn tumọ̀ sí?

english: It means 1,100 children infected each day -- 1,100 children each day, infected with HIV.
yoruba: Ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé ọ̀rùn-lé-lẹ́gbẹ́rùn ọmọ ló ń ní àkóràn lójoojúmọ́ – ọ̀rùn-lé-lẹ́gbẹ́rùn (1,100) ọmọ lójoojúmọ́, ló ń ní àkóràn kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: And where do they come from?
yoruba: Níbo ni wọ́n ti ń wá?

english: Well, less than one comes from the United States.
yoruba: Ó dáa, ó dín ní ẹyọ̀kan ni ó ń wá láti orílẹ̀-ède Amẹ́ríkà.

english: One, on average, comes from Europe.
yoruba: Ẹyọ̀kan, ní àròpin, ni ó ń wá láti ilẹ̀ Yúróòpù.

english: 100 come from Asia and the Pacific.
yoruba: Ọgọ́rùún wá láti agbọn Asia àti Pacific.

english: And each day, a thousand babies -- a thousand babies are born each day with HIV in Africa.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kànkan, ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àwọn ìkókó – ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àwọn ìkókó ni wọ́n ń bí lọ́jó kànkan pẹ̀lú kòkòro apa sójà ara ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: So again, I look at the globe here and the disproportionate share of HIV in Africa.
yoruba: Lẹ́ẹ̀kan síi, mo wo àwòran àgbáyé tó wà níbí àti ìpín kòkòro apa sójà ara ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ti kọjá àyè.

english: And let's look at another map.
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí á wo àwòrán orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn.

english: That thin sliver you see here, that's Africa.
yoruba: Ilà fàdákà tírín tí ẹ rí níbí yìí, ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nìyẹn.

english: And it's the same with nurses.
yoruba: Bákan náà ni pẹ̀lú àwọn nọ́ọ́sì.

english: The truth is sub-Saharan Africa has 24 percent of the global disease burden and yet only three percent of the world's health care workers.
yoruba: Ọtítọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé ìwò-oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní ìdá mẹ́rìn-lé-lógún (24%) wàhálà ààrùn àgbáyé síbẹ̀ ìdá mẹ́ta àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera àgbáyé péré.

english: That means doctors and nurses simply don't have the time to take care of patients.
yoruba: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn oníṣègùn òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì ò ní àkókò láti tọ́jú àwọn aláìsàn.

english: A nurse in a busy clinic will see 50 to 100 patients in a day, which leaves her just minutes per patient -- minutes per patient.
yoruba: Nọ́ọ́sì kan ní ààyè ìtọ́jú máa rí àdọ́ta (50) sí ọgọ́rùn (100) àwọn aláìsàn lọ́jọ́ kan, tí ó fun ní ànfàní ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀ fún aláìsàn kan -- ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀ fún aláìsàn kan.

english: And so when we look at these PMTCT programs, what does it mean?
yoruba: Tí a bá wá wo àwọn èto PMTCT wọ̀nyí, kí ló túmọ̀ sí?

english: Well, back in 2001, when there was just a simple test and a single dose of a drug, a nurse, in the course of her few minutes with a patient, would have to counsel for the HIV test, perform the HIV test, explain the results, dispense a single dose of the drug, Nevirapine, explain how to take it, discuss infant feeding options, reinforce infant feeding, and test the baby -- in minutes.
yoruba: Ó dáa, ní ọdún 2001, nígbà tí ó jẹ́ wí pé àyẹ̀wò péréte àti hóró òògùn kan ló wà, nọ́ọ́sì kan, lásíkò ìṣẹ́jú péréte rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú aláìsàn kan, ní láti ṣe ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ fún àyẹ̀wo kòkòro apa sójà ara, ṣe àyẹ̀wo kòkòrò apa sójà ara, ṣàlàye èsì, fún wọn ní hóró òògùn kan, Nevirapine, ṣàlàye bí wọn ó ṣe lò ó, jírórò àwọn ẹ̀yan ìfọ́mọlọ́mú, ṣe ìwúrí fún ìfọ́mọlọ́mú, kó sì ṣe àyẹ̀wò fún ìkókó náà – ní ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀.

english: Well, fortunately since 2001, we've got new treatments, new tests, and we're far more successful, but we don't have any more nurses.
yoruba: Ó dáa, Oríire ni pé láti ọdún 2001, a ti ní àwọn ìtọ́jú tuntun, àyẹ̀wò tuntun, a sì ti ṣe àṣeyọrí jìnà, ṣùgbọ́n a kò ní àwọn nọ́ọ́sì púpọ̀ mọ́.

english: And so these are the tests a nurse now has to do in those same few minutes.
yoruba: Àwọn àyẹ̀wò wọ̀nyí ní nọ́ọ́sì kan ní láti ṣe láàrín ìṣẹ́jú péréte kan náà.

english: It's not possible -- it doesn't work.
yoruba: Kò ṣe é ṣe -- kò kí ń ṣiṣẹ́.

english: And so we need to find better ways of providing care.
yoruba: Nítorí náà a ní láti wá àwọn ọ̀nà tó dára láti pèsè ìtọ́jú.

english: This is a picture of a maternal health clinic in Africa -- mothers coming, pregnant and with their babies.
yoruba: Èyí ni àwòran ilé-ìwòsàn ìgbèbí ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ -- àwọn ìyá tó ń wá, tí wọ́n lóyún tí wọ́n wá pẹ̀lú àwọn ìkókó wọn.

english: These women are here for care, but we know that just doing a test, just giving someone a drug, it's not enough.
yoruba: Àwọn obìnrin wònyí wá síbí fún ìtọ́jú, ṣùgbọ́n a mọ̀ wí pé ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò kan, fífún ènìyàn lógùn nìkan, kò tó.

english: Meds don't equal medical care.
yoruba: Òògùn ò dọ́gba pẹ̀lú ìtọ́jú.

english: Doctors and nurses, frankly, don't have the time or skills to tell people what to do in ways they understand.
yoruba: Àwọn Oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì, ní tòótọ́, ò ní àkókò tàbí ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe láti sọ fún àwọn ènìyàn ǹkan tí wọn yóò ṣe ní ọ̀nà tí yóò yé wọn.

english: I'm a doctor -- I tell people things to do, and I expect them to follow my guidance -- because I'm a doctor; I went to Harvard -- but the reality is, if I tell a patient, "You should have safer sex.
yoruba: Mo jẹ́ onímọ̀-ìṣègùn -- mo máa ń sọ fún àwọn ènìyàn ohun tí wọn yóò ṣe, mo dẹ̀ lérò wí pé wọn yóò tẹ̀lé ìmọ̀ràn mi -- nítorí oníṣégùn-òyìnbó ni mí; mo lọ sí Havard – ṣùgbọ́n òtítọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé, tí mo bá sọ fún aláìsàn kan, "kí ẹ ní ìbálópọ̀ aláìléwu.

english: You should always use a condom," and yet, in her relationship, she's not empowered -- what's going to happen?
yoruba: Kí ẹ máa lo rọ́bà ìdáábò bò ní gbogbo ìgbà, "síbẹ̀, nínú àjọṣepọ̀ rẹ̀, kò ní agbára – kí ni yóò ṣẹlẹ̀?

english: If I tell her to take her medicines every day and yet, no one in the household knows about her illness, so it's just not going to work.
yoruba: Tí mo bá sọ fún-un wí pé kó lo òògun rẹ̀ lójoojúmọ́ síbẹ̀, kò sí ẹnìkan ní ìdílé rẹ̀ to mọ̀ nípa àìsan rẹ̀.

english: And so we need to do more, we need to do it differently, we need to do it in ways that are affordable and accessible and can be taken to scale, which means it can be done everywhere.
yoruba: Nítorí náà a ní láti ṣe síi, a ní láti ṣe é lọ́nà tó yátọ̀, a ní láti ṣe é ní ọ̀nà tí kò ní gaju ara lọ tí wọn yóò sì ní ànfàní síi ti wọ́n lè gbe sórí òṣùwọ̀n, tó túmọ̀ sí wí pé wọ́n lè ṣe é níbikíbi.

english: So, I want to tell you a story -- I want to take you on a little trip.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, mo fẹ́ sọ ìtàn kan fún yín – mo fẹ́ múu yín rin ìrìnàjò kékeré kan.

english: Imagine yourself, if you can, you're a young woman in Africa, you're going to the hospital or clinic.
yoruba: Ẹ wòye ara yín, tí o bá lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, o jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́bìnrin nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ò ń lọ sí ilé-ìwòsàn tàbí ààyè-ìtọ́jú.

english: You go in for a test and you find out that you're pregnant, and you're delighted.
yoruba: Ẹ wọlé fún àyẹ̀wò o wá mọ̀ wí pé o ti loyún, inúù rẹ sì dùn.

english: And then they give you another test and they tell you you're HIV-positive, and you're devastated.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni wọ́n bá fún ẹ ní àyẹ̀wò míràn wọ́n sì sọ fún ẹ wí pé o ní kòkòro apa sójà ara, ó sì rẹ̀ ọ́ wẹ̀sì.

english: And the nurse takes you into a room, and she tells you about the tests and HIV and the medicines you can take and how to take care of yourself and your baby, and you hear none of it.
yoruba: Nọ́ọ́sì náà bá mú ẹ lọ sínú yàrá kan, ó sì ń sọ fún ẹ nípa àwọn àyẹ̀wò náà àti kòkòro apa sójà ara àti àwọn òògùn tí ẹ lè lò àti bí ẹ ó ṣe ṣe ìtọ́jú ara yín àti ọmọ yín, ẹ ò sì gbọ́ ǹkankan nínu rẹ̀.

english: All you're hearing is, "I'm going to die, and my baby is going to die.
yoruba: Gbogbo ǹkan tí ẹ̀ ń gbọ́ ni, "Màá kú, ọmọọ̀ mi náà máa kú.

english: And then you're out on the street, and you don't know where to go.
yoruba: O bá bọ́ sí ìgboro, o kò sì mọ ibi à á yà sí.

english: And you don't know who you can talk to, because the truth is, HIV is so stigmatizing that if you partner, your family, anyone in your home, you're likely to be thrown out without any means of support.
yoruba: Ẹ ò sì mọ ẹni tí ẹ lè fi ọ̀rọ̀ lọ̀, nítorí ọ̀títọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé, kòkòro apa sójà ara máa ń fa ìdẹ́yẹsí débi wí pé tí olólùfẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ, ẹbíì rẹ, ẹnikẹ́ni nínu iléè rẹ, wọ́n lè lé ẹ síta láìsí àtìlẹyìn Kankan.

english: And this -- this is the face and story of HIV in Africa today.
yoruba: Èyí -- eyí ni ojú àti ìtan kòkòro apa sójà ara ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lónì.

english: But we're here to talk about possible solutions and some good news.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a wá síbí láti wá sọ nípa àwọn ọ̀nà-àbáyọ àti àwọn ìròyin ayọ̀.

english: And I want to change the story a little bit.
yoruba: Mo dè fẹ́ ṣe àyípadà ìtàn yìí díẹ̀ si.

english: Take the same mother, and the nurse, after she gives her her test, takes her to a room.
yoruba: Ẹ mú ìyá yìí kan náà, àti nọ́ọ́sì náà, lẹ́yìn tó bá fún-un ní àyẹ̀wo rẹ̀, ó múu lọ sí yàrá kan.

english: The door opens and there's a room full of mothers, mothers with babies, and they're sitting, and they're talking, they're listening.
yoruba: Ilẹ̀kùn náà ṣí yàrá náà sì kún fún àwọn ìyá, àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n lọ́mọ lọ́wọ́, tí wọ́n jókòó, tí wọ́n ń sọ́rọ̀, tí wọ́n ń tẹ́tí.

english: They're drinking tea, they're having sandwiches.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń mu tíì, wọ́n ń jẹ búrẹ́dì.

english: And she goes inside, and woman comes up to her and says, "Welcome to mothers2mothers.
yoruba: Ó sì wọlé lọ, obìnrin kan sì dìde sí i ó sì wí pé, "káábọ̀ sí ìya sí ìyá.

english: Have a seat.
yoruba: Mú ìjókòó.

english: You're safe here.
yoruba: Ààbó wà fún ọ níbí.

english: We're all HIV-positive.
yoruba: Gbogbo wa la ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: You're going to be okay.
yoruba: Aráà rẹ yóò yá.

english: You're going to live.
yoruba: Wàá gbáyé.

english: Your baby is going to be HIV-negative.
yoruba: Ọmọọ̀ rẹ ò ní ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: We view mothers as a community's single greatest resource.
yoruba: A rí àwọn ìyá gẹ́gẹ́ bí èròjà kan ṣoṣo tó tóbi jù láwùjọ.

english: Mothers take care of the children, take care of the home.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá máa ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn ọmọ, ṣe ìtọ́jú ilé.

english: So often the men are gone.
yoruba: Lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà àwọn ọkùnrin ti lọ.

english: They're working, or they're not part of the household.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́, tàbí wọ̀n ò sí lára ìdílé náà.

english: Our organization, mothers2mothers, enlists women with HIV as care providers.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ wa, ìyá sí ìyá, máa ń gba àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara gẹ́gẹ́ bi elétò ìlera.

english: We bring mothers who have HIV, who've been through these PMTCT programs in the very facilities, to come back and work side by side with doctors and nurses as part of the health care team.
yoruba: A máa ń mú àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara, tí wọ́n ti la èto PMTCT wọ̀nyí kọjá ní àyè yìí, láti padà wá ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀kan lára ikọ̀ òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera.

english: These mothers, we call them mentor mothers, are able to engage women who, just like themselves, pregnant with babies, have found out about being HIV-positive, who need support and education.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá wọ̀nyí, à ń pè wọ́n ní àwọn ìya olùbánidámọ́ràn, máa ń jírórò pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin tí, bí àwọn náà, wọ́n lóyún ọmọ, tí wọ́n ti mọ̀ wí pé àwọ́n ti ní kòkòro apa sójà ara, tí wọ́n nílò àtìlẹyìn àti ẹ̀kọ́.

english: And they support them around the diagnosis and educate them about how to take their medicines, how to take care of themselves, how to take care of their babies.
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún wọn nípa àyẹ̀wò wọ́n sì máa ń kọ́ wọn lẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa bí wọn ó ṣe lo òògun wọn, bí wọn ó ṣe ṣe ìtọ́jú ara wọn, bí wọn ó ṣe tọ́jú àwọn ìkókó wọn.

english: Consider: if you needed surgery, you would want the best possible technical surgeon, right?
yoruba: Rò ó wò: tí ẹ bá nílò iṣẹ́ abẹ, ẹ máa fẹ́ àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nínu iṣẹ́ abẹ tó ṣe é ṣe jùlọ, àbí?

english: But if you wanted to understand what that surgery would do to your life, you'd like to engage someone, someone who's had the procedure.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí ẹ bá fẹ́ mọ ohun tí iṣẹ́ abẹ yẹn máa ṣe fún ayéè yín, ẹ máa nífẹ̀ láti jírórò pẹ̀lú ẹnìkan, ẹnìkan tó ti la irú ìgbésẹ̀ náà kọjá.

english: Patients are experts on their own experience, and they can share that experience with others.
yoruba: Àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ ni àwọn aláìsàn nípa ìrírí wọn, wọ́n lè sọ ìrírí yẹn fún àwọn tókù.

english: This is the medical care that goes beyond just medicines.
yoruba: Èyí ni ìtọ́jú ajẹmọ́ ìṣègùn tó kọjá òògùn lásán.

english: So the mothers who work for us, they come from the communities in which they work.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún wa, wọ́n wá láti àwọn agbègbè tí wọ́n ti ń ṣiṣẹ́.

english: They're hired -- they're paid as professional members of the health care teams, just like doctors and nurses.
yoruba: A gbà wọ́n -- wọ́n ń gba owó gẹ́gẹ́ bi akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ lára ikọ̀ àwọn onímọ̀ ìlera, bíi àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì.

english: And we open bank accounts for them and they're paid directly into the accounts, because their money's protected; the men can't take it away from them.
yoruba: A ṣí àpò-àṣùwọn ilé-ìfowópamọ́ fún wọn a dẹ̀ ń sanwó tààrà sínu àpò-àṣùwọn wọn, nítorí ààbó wà fún owó wọn; àwọn ọkùnrin ò lè gbà á lọ́wọ wọn.

english: They go through two to three weeks of rigorous curriculum-based education, training.
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń la ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ oní kọ̀ríkúlọ́ọ̀mù alágbára olósẹ̀ méjì tàbí mẹ́ta kọjá, ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: Now, doctors and nurses -- they too get trained.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì -- àwọn náà ń gba ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: But so often, they only get trained once, so they're not aware of new medicines, new guidelines as they come out.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà, ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ni wọ́n máa ń gba ìkọ́ni, nítorí náà wọn ò nímọ̀ nípa òògùn tuntun, ìlànà ìtọ́sọ́nà tuntun bí wọ́n ṣe ń jáde.

english: Our mentor mothers get trained every single year and retrained.
yoruba: Àwọn ìya olùbánidámọ̀ran wa máa ń gba ìkọ́ni lọ́dún kànkan àti àtúnkọ́.

english: And so doctors and nurses -- they look up to them as experts.
yoruba: Nítorí náà àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì -- wọ́n máa ń wọjú wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bi àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀.

english: Imagine that: a woman, a former patient, being able to educate her doctor for the first time and educate the other patients that she's taking care of.
yoruba: Ẹ Wòye pé: obìnrin kan, tó jẹ́ aláìsàn nígbà kan rí, tó lè kọ́ onímọ̀-ìṣègun rẹ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tó sì lè kọ́ àwọn aláìsàn tókù tó ń ṣe ìtọ́jú wọn.

english: Our organization has three goals.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ wa ní àfojúsùn mẹ́ta.

english: The first, to prevent mother-to-child transmission.
yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́, láti dèna àkóràn ìyá-sí-ọmọ.

english: The second: keep mothers healthy, keep mothers alive, keep the children alive -- no more orphans.
yoruba: Ìkejì: kí ìyá wà lálààfíà, kí ìyá wà láyé, kí ọmọ náà wà lááyé -- kò sí ọmọ òrúkàn mọ́.

english: And the third, and maybe the most grand, is to find ways to empower women, enable them to fight the stigma and to live positive and productive lives with HIV.
