yoruba: Ìkẹ́ta, bóyá èyí tó ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ, ni láti wá ọ̀nà láti ró àwọn obìnrin lágbára, fún wọn ní ànfàní láti gbógun ti ìdẹ́yẹsí àti láti gbé ìgbe ayé rere ìgbeayé tí yóò so èso rere pẹ̀lu kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: So how do we do it?
yoruba: Báwo la ó ṣe ṣe é?

english: Well, maybe the most important engagement is the one-to-one, seeing patients one-to-one, educating them, supporting them, explaining how they can take care of themselves.
yoruba: Bóyá ibánisòrọ̀ tó ṣe pàtàkì jù ni ìwọ-kan-èmi-kan, rírí àwọn aláìsàn ní ìwọ-kan-èmi-kan, kíkọ́ wọn lẹ́kọ̀ọ́, ṣíṣe àtìlẹyìn fún wọn, ṣí ṣálàyé bí wọn ó ṣe ṣe ìtọ́jú ara wọn.

english: We go beyond that; we try to bring in the husbands, the partners.
yoruba: A máa ń tayọ ìyẹn; a máa ń gbìyànjú láti mú àwọn ọkọ wọlé, àwọn olólùfẹ́.

english: In Africa, it's very, very hard to engage men.
yoruba: Ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ó le gidi gan láti jírórò pẹ̀lú àwọn ọkùnrin.

english: Men are not frequently part of pregnancy care.
yoruba: Àwọn ọkùnrin kìí fi bẹ́ẹ̀ sí lára ìtọ́jú oyún.

english: But in Rwanda, in one country, they've got a policy that a woman can't come for care unless she brings the father of the baby with her -- that's the rule.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda, ní orílẹ̀-èdè kan, wọ́n ti ní òfin pé obìnrin ò lè wá fún ìtọ́jú àyàfi tí ó bá mú bàba ọmọ wá pẹ̀lu rẹ̀ -- òfin yẹn nìyẹn.

english: And so the father and the mother, together, go through the counseling and the testing.
yoruba: Nítorí náà bàbá àti ìyá, lápapọ̀, jọ máa ń la ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti àyẹ̀wò kọjá ni.

english: The father and the mother, together, they get the results.
yoruba: Bàbá àti ìyá, lápapọ̀, jọ máa ń gba èsì ni.

english: And this is so important in breaking through the stigma.
yoruba: Èyí sì ṣe pàtàkì láti rí ọ̀nà àbáyọ kúrò nínu ìdẹ́yẹsí.

english: Disclosure is so central to prevention.
yoruba: Sísọ ọ́ jáde ṣe pàtàkì púpọ̀ fún ìdènà.

english: How do you have safer sex, how do you use a condom regularly if there hasn't been disclosure?
yoruba: Báwo ni ẹ ṣe lè ní ìbálópọ̀ aláìléwu, báwo ni ẹ ṣe lè lo rọ́bà ìdáábòbò lóórè-kóórè tí kò bá sí sísọ?

english: Disclosure is so important to treatment, because again, people need the support of family members and friends to take their medicines regularly.
yoruba: Sísọ ọ́ ṣe pàtàkì púpọ̀ fún ìtọ́jú, torí lẹ́ẹ̀kan síi, àwọn ènìyán nílò àtìlẹyìn àwọn ẹbí àti ọ̀rẹ́ láti lo òògun wọn lóórè-kóórè.

english: We also work in groups.
yoruba: A tún máa ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìsòrí-sòrí.

english: Now the groups, it's not like me lecturing, but what happens is women, they come together -- under the support and guidance of our mentor mothers -- they come together, and they share their personal experiences.
yoruba: Báyìí àwọn ìsọ̀rí náà, kìí ṣe pé mò ń ṣe ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́, ṣùgbọ́n ǹkan tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní wí pé àwọn obìnrin, wọ́n máa ń kórajọ -- lábẹ́ àtìlẹyìn àti ìtọ́sọ́nà àwọn ìyá olùbánidámọ̀ran wa -- wọ́n máa ń kórajọ, wọ́n sì máa ń sọ ìrírí wọn.

english: And it's through the sharing that people get tactics of how to take care of themselves, how to disclose how to take medicines.
yoruba: Nípasẹ sísọ ìrírí náà ni àwọn ènìyàn ti má a ń rí ọgbọ́n bí wọ́n ṣe lè tọ́jú ara wọn, bí wọn ó ṣe sọ ọ́ bí wọn ó ṣe lo òògùn.

english: And then there's the community outreach, engaging women in their communities.
yoruba: And then there's the community outreach, engaging women in their communities. Ìkéde agbègbé náà tún wà, ìjírórò pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin ní àwùjọ wọn.

english: If we can change the way households believe and think, we can change the way communities believe and think.
yoruba: Tí a bá lè mú àyípada bá ìgbàgbọ́ àwọn ìdíle àti bí wọ́n ṣe ń ronú, a lè mú àyípadà bá ìgbàgbọ́ àwùjọ àti bí wọ́n ṣe ń ronú.

english: And if we can change enough communities, we can change national attitudes.
yoruba: Tí a bá lè mú àyípadà bá àwùjọ tó pọ̀, a lè mú àyípadà bá ìhùwàsí orílẹ̀-èdè.

english: We can change national attitudes to women and national attitudes to HIV.
yoruba: A lè mú àyípadà bá ìhà orílẹ̀-èdè sí àwọn obìnrin àti ìhà orílẹ̀-èdè sí kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: The hardest barrier really is around stigma reduction.
yoruba: Ìdíwọ́ tó lágbára jù lóòtọ́ sopọ̀ mọ́ àdínkù ìdẹ́yẹsí.

english: We have the medicines, we have the tests, but how do you reduce the stigma?
yoruba: A ní àwọn òògùn, a ní àyẹ̀wò, ṣùgbọ́n báwo la ṣe lè mú àdínkù bá ìdẹ́yẹsí?

english: And it's important about disclosure.
yoruba: Ó sì ṣe pàtàkì sí sísọ ọ́ jáde.

english: So, a couple years ago, one of the mentor mothers came back, and she told me a story.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, ní bíi ọdún díẹ̀ sẹ́yìn, ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìyá olùbánidámọ̀ran náà padà wá, ó dẹ̀ sọ ìtàn kan fún mi.

english: She had been asked by one of the clients to go to the home of the client, because the client wanted to tell the mother and her brothers and sisters about her HIV status, and she was afraid to go by herself.
yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn aláìsan rẹ̀ sọ fún-un wí pé kó lọ sí ilé òhun, nítorí aláìsàn náà fẹ́ sọ fún ìyá àti àwọn ọmọ ìya rẹ̀ lọ́kùnrin àti lóbìnrin nípa ipò kòkòro apa sójà ara rẹ̀, ẹ̀rú sì ń bà á láti lọ fúnra rẹ̀.

english: And so the mentor mother went along with.
yoruba: Ni ìyá olùbánidámọ́ràn náà bá tẹ̀le lọ.

english: And the patient walked into the house and said to her mother and siblings, "I have something to tell you.
yoruba: Ni aláìsàn náà bá rìn wọnú ilé náà ó bá sọ fún ìya rẹ̀ àti àwọn ẹbí rẹ̀, "Mo ní ǹkan láti sọ fún yín.

english: I'm HIV-positive.
yoruba: Mo ti ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: And everybody was quiet.
yoruba: Gbogbo wọ́n dákẹ́.

english: And then her oldest brother stood up and said, "I too have something to tell you.
yoruba: Ni ẹ̀gbọn rẹ̀ àgbà lọ́kùnrin náà bá dìde ó ní, "èmi náà ní ǹkan láti sọ fún yín.

english: I'm HIV-positive.
yoruba: Mo ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: I've been afraid to tell everybody.
yoruba: Ẹ̀rù ló ń bàmí láti sọ fún gbogbo yín.

english: And then this older sister stood up and said, I too am living with the virus, and I've been ashamed.
yoruba: Ni ẹ̀gbọn rẹ̀ àgbà lóbìnrin yìí bá dìde ó ní, "Èmi náà ń gbé pẹ̀lu kòkòrò náà, ojú sì ti ń tìmí.

english: And then her younger brother stood up and said, I'm also positive.
yoruba: Ni àbúro rẹ̀ lọ́kùnrin náà bá dìde ó ní, "Èmi náà ní i.

english: I thought you were going to throw me out of the family.
yoruba: Mo lérò wí pé ẹ máa lémi kúrò nínú ẹbí ni.

english: And you see where this is going.
yoruba: Ẹ rí ibi tí èyí ń lọ.

english: The last sister stood up and said, "I'm also positive.
yoruba: Obìnrin tó gbẹ́yìn dìde ó ní, "èmi náà ní i.

english: I thought you were going to hate me.
yoruba: Mo lérò wí pé ẹ máa kórìra mi ni.

english: And there they were, all of them together for the first time being able to share this experience for the first time and to support each other for the first time.
yoruba: " Àwọn wá rèé, gbogbo wọn lápapọ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n lè sọ ìrírí yìí fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ àti láti ṣe àtilẹyìn fún ara wọn fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́.

english: (Video) Female Narrator: Women come to us, and they are crying and scared.
yoruba: (fọ́rán aláwòrán) Obìnrin Asọ̀tàn: Àwọn obìnrin máa ń wá sọ́dọ wa, wọ́n ń sukún ẹ̀rú sì ń bà wọ́n.

english: I tell them my story, that I am HIV-positive, but my child is HIV-negative.
yoruba: Mo sọ ìtan tèmi fún wọn, pé mo ni kòkòro apa sójà ara, ṣùgbọ́n ọmọọ̀ mi ò ní.

english: I tell them, "You are going to make it, and you will raise a healthy baby.
yoruba: Mo sọ fún wọn, "Ẹ máa yán-an yọ, ẹ ó sì re ọmọ tí ìléra rẹ̀ pé.

english: I am proof that there is hope.
yoruba: " Èrí ni mo jẹ́ pé ìrètí ń bẹ.

english: Mitchell Besser: Remember the images I showed you of how few doctors and nurses there are in Africa.
yoruba: Mitchell Besser: Ẹ rantí àwọn àwòrán tí mo fi hàn yín nípa ìwọ̀nba awọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì tí wọ́n wà ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: And it is a crisis in health care systems.
yoruba: Wàhálà ló sì jẹ́ sí ètò ìlera.

english: Even as we have more tests and more drugs, we can't reach people; we don't have enough providers.
yoruba: Kódà bí a ṣe ń ní àyẹ̀wò àti òògùn si, a ò léè dọ́dọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn; a ò ní àwọn onímò-ìlera tó tó.

english: So we talk in terms of what we call task-shifting.
yoruba: À máa ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ǹkan tí à ń pè ní ìgbaṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni.

english: Task-shifting is traditionally when you take health care services from one provider and have another provider do it.
yoruba: ìgbaṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ ara ẹni jẹ́ àṣà nígbà tí ẹ bá gba iṣẹ́ ìlera láti ọwọ́ onímọ̀-ìlera kan tí onímọ̀-ìlera mìíràn sì ṣe é.

english: Typically, it's a doctor giving a job to a nurse.
yoruba: Bó ṣe rí, oníṣégùn-òyìnbó lo ń gbé iṣẹ́ fún nọ́ọ́sì.

english: And the issue in Africa is that there are fewer nurses, really than doctors, and so we need to find new paradigm for health care.
yoruba: Wàhálà tó wà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni wí pé ìwọ̀nba àwọn nọ́ọ́sì ló wà, ju àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó lọ, nítorí náà a nílò láti wá ètò tuntun fún ètò ìlera.

english: How do you build a better health care system?
yoruba: Báwo ni ẹ ṣe lè pèse ètò ìlera gidi?

english: We've chosen to redefine the health care system as a doctor, a nurse and a mentor mother.
yoruba: A ti pinnu láti ṣe àtúnṣe ètò ìlera gẹ́gẹ́ bi oníṣégùn-òyìnbó, nọ́ọ́sì àti ìya olùbánidámọ́ràn.

english: And so what nurses do is that they ask the mentor mothers to explain how to take the drugs, the side effects.
yoruba: Nítorí náà ǹkan tí àwọn nọ́ọ́sì máa ń ṣe ni wí pé wọn máa ń sọ fún àwọn ìya olùbánidámọ́ràn pé kọ́ ṣàlàye bi wọn yóò ṣe lo òògùn, àti ewu rẹ̀.

english: They delegate education about infant feeding, family planning, safer sex, actions that nurses simple just don't have time for.
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń ṣe ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa fífún ìkókó lóunjẹ, ìfètò-sẹ́bí, ìbálópọ̀ aláìléwu, àwọn iṣẹ́ tí àwọn nọ́ọ́sì ò ní àkókò fún.

english: So we go back to the prevention of mother to child transmission.
yoruba: A padà síbi ìdèna àkóràn ìyá sí ọmọ.

english: The world is increasingly seeing these programs as the bridge to comprehensive maternal and child health.
yoruba: Gbogbo àgbáyé ń rí àwọn ètò wọ̀nyí gẹ́gẹ́ bi afárá sí ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ ìlera ìyá àti ọmọ.

english: And our organization helps women across that bridge.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ wa ń ran àwọn obìnrin lọ́wọ́ láti gun afárá yẹn.

english: The care doesn't stop when the baby's born -- we deal with the ongoing health of the mother and baby, ensuring that they live healthy, successful lives.
yoruba: Ìtójú náà ò kín dúró nígbà tí wọ́n bá bí ọmọ náà -- a máa ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìtẹ̀síwájú ìlera ìyá àti ọmọ, láti ríi dájú pé wọ́n gbé ìgbe ayé àlàáfíà, ìgbeayé aláṣeyọrí.

english: Our organization works on three levels.
yoruba: Ilé-iṣẹ́ wa ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìpele mẹ́ta.

english: The first, at the patient level -- mothers and babies keeping babies from getting HIV, keeping mothers healthy to raise them.
yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́, ní ìpele aláìsàn -- àwọn ìya àti àwọn ọmọ dídáábòbo àwọn ọmọ kúrò níbi kíkó kòkòro apa sójà ara, mímú kí àwọn ìyá wà láláàfíà láti rè wọ́n.

english: The second, communities -- empowering women.
yoruba: Ìkejì, àwọn àwùjọ -- ríró àwọn obìnrin lágbára.

english: They become leaders within their communities.
yoruba: Wọ́n di adarí láàrín àwùjọ wọn.

english: They change the way communities think -- we need to change attitudes to HIV.
yoruba: Wọ́n mú àyípadà bá bí àwọn àwùjọ ṣe ń ronú -- a nílò láti mú àyípadà bá ìhà kíkọ sí kòkòro apa sójà ara

english: We need to change attitudes to women in Africa.
yoruba: A nílò láti mú àyípadà bá ìhà kíkọ sí àwọn obìnrin ní ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

english: We have to do that.
yoruba: A ní láti ṣe ìyẹn.

english: And then rework the level of the health care systems, building stronger health care systems.
yoruba: Ká wá ṣe àtúnṣe ìpele ètò ìlera, ìṣẹ̀dá ètò ìlera tó lágbára.

english: Our health care systems are broken.
yoruba: Ètò ìlera wá ti túká.

english: They're not going to work the way they're currently designed.
yoruba: Wọn ò ní ṣiṣẹ́ bí wọ́n ṣe ṣe àto wọn lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

english: And so doctors and nurses who need to try to change people's behaviors don't have the skills, don't have the time -- our mentor mothers do.
yoruba: Nítorí náà àwọn onímọ̀-ìlera àti àwọn nọ́ọ́sì tí wọ́n ní láti mú àyípadà bá ìwà àwọn ènìyàn ò ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe rẹ̀, wọn ò ní àsìko rẹ̀ -- àwọn ìyá olùbánidámọ̀ran wa níi.

english: And so in redefining the health care teams by bringing the mentor mothers in, we can do that.
yoruba: Nítorí náà láti ṣe àtúnṣe àwọn ikọ̀ ètò ìlera pẹ̀lú mímú àwọn ìyá olùbánidámọ́ràn wọlé, a lè ṣe ìyen.

english: I started the program in Capetown, South Africa back in 2001.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ ètò náà ní Capetown, orílẹ̀-ède South Africa ní ọdún 2001.

english: It was at that point, just the spark of an idea.
yoruba: Ní àyè yẹn ni, ògúná èrò kan lásán.

english: Referencing Steven Johnson's very lovely speech yesterday on where ideas come from, I was in the shower at the time -- I was alone.
yoruba: Títọ́ka sí ọrọ̀ dídùn Steven Johnson lánà lóri ibi tí èró ti ń wá, mo wà nínú ilé-ìwẹ̀ ní àsìkò náà -- mo dá wà ni.

english: (Laughter) The program is now working in nine countries, we have 670 program sites, we're seeing about 230,000 women every month, we're employing 1,600 mentor mothers, and last year, they enrolled 300,000 HIV-positive pregnant women and mothers.
yoruba: (Ẹ̀rín) Ètò náà ti wá ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè mẹ́sàn-án, a ní ibùdó ètò ojì-din-lẹwá din ni ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbẹ́rin (670), à ń rí àwọn obìnrin tó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ojì-din-lẹwá-le-nigba (230,000) lóṣooṣù, à ń gba ẹgbẹ̀jọ (1,600) àwọn ìyá olùbánidámọ́ràn síṣẹ́, ní ọdún tó kọjá, wọ́n gba àwọn obìnrin olóyún àti àwọn ìyá tó ni kòkòro apa sójà ara bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọ̀ọ̀dúnrún (300,000).

english: That is 20 percent of the global HIV-positive pregnant women -- 20 percent of the world.
yoruba: Ìyẹn jẹ́ ìda ogún àwọn aláboyún tó ní kòkòro apa sójà ara ní àgbáyé -- ìda ogún (20%) àgbáyé.

english: What's extraordinary is how simple the premise is.
yoruba: Ǹkan tó kọjá òye ni bí ọ̀rọ̀ yìí ṣe rọrùn tó.

english: Mothers with HIV caring for mothers with HIV.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá tó ní kòkòro apa sójà ara tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìtọ́jú fún àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: Past patients taking care of present patients.
yoruba: Àwọn aláìsàn nígbà kan rí tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn tó ń ṣáìsàn lọ́wọ́.

english: And empowerment through employment -- reducing stigma.
yoruba: Àti ìrónilágbára nípasẹ ìgbanisíṣẹ́ -- mímú àdínkù bá ìdẹ́yẹsí.

english: (Video) Female Narrator: There is hope, hope that one day we shall win this fight against HIV and AIDS.
yoruba: (fọ́rán aláwòrán) Obìnrin Asọ̀tàn: ìrètí wà, ìrètí pé lọ́jọ́ kan a ó borí ìjà yìí kojú kòkòro apa sójà ara àti ìsọdọ̀lẹ àjẹsára.

english: Each person must know their HIV status.
yoruba: Èyàn kànkan gbọ́dọ̀ mọ ipo kòkòro apa sójà ara wọn.

english: Those who are HIV-negative must know how to stay negative.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọn ò ní kòkòro apa sójà ara gbọ́dọ̀ mọ bí wọn ò ṣe ní kó o.

english: Those who are HIV-infected must know how to take care of themselves.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara gbọ́dọ̀ mọ bí wọn ó ṣe ṣe ìtọ́jú ara wọn.

english: HIV-positive pregnant women must get PMTCT services in order to have HIV-negative babies.
yoruba: Àwọn aláboyún tí wọ́n ní kòkòro apa sójà ara gbọ́dọ̀ gba iṣẹ́ PMTCT láti lè ní àwọn ìkókó tí ò ní kòkòro apa sójà ara.

english: All of this is possible, if we each contribute to this fight.
yoruba: Gbogbo èyí ṣe é ṣe, tí ẹnìkànkan wa bá dásí ìjà yìí.

english: MB: Simple solutions to complex problems.
yoruba: MB: Àwọn ọ̀nà àbáyọ tó rọrùn sí àwọn ìṣòro àmúdijú.

english: Mothers caring for mothers.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìtọ́jú fún àwọn ìyá.

english: It's transformational.
yoruba: Àyípadà ni.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: How women are revolutionizing Rwanda
yoruba: Bí àwọn obìnrin ṣe ń mú àyípadà bá orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda.

english: I came back to my home of Rwanda two years after the 1994 genocide against the Tutsi.
yoruba: Mo padà sí ilé mi ní orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda ní odún méjì lẹ́yin ìṣekúpani ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà ọdún 1994 kojúu Tutsi.

english: The country was devastated.
yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè náà ti bàjẹ́.

english: The children I was caring for in the hospitals were dying from treatable conditions, because we didn't have equipment or medicine to save them.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ tí mò ń tọ́jú nílé-ìwòsàn ń kú látara àìsàn tó ṣe é tọ́jú, nítorí a ò ní irinṣẹ́ tàbí òògùn láti dóòla wọn.

english: I was tempted to pack my bag and run away.
yoruba: Èyí fẹ́ mú mi kó àpamọ́ mi kí n sì sálọ.

english: But I debated with myself.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo ṣe àríyànjiyàn pẹ̀lú ara mi.

english: And because I'm really dedicated to social justice and equity, and there were only five pediatricians in total for millions of children in Rwanda, I decided to stay.
yoruba: Nítorí mo ní ìfọkànsìn sí ìdájọ́ àwùjọ àti ìdọ́gba, àwọn aṣètọ́jú-ọmọdé márùn-ún ló sí wà fún mílíọ́nù àwọn ọmọdé ní orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda, mo pinnu láti dúró.

english: But among the people who have motivated my decision to stay, there were some fantastic women of Rwanda, some women who had faced the genocide and survived it.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lára àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ṣe kóríyá fún ìpinnu mi láti dúró, àwọn obìnrin takun-takun wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda, àwọn obìnrin kan tí wọ́n ti kojú ìṣekúpani ẹlẹ́yámẹ̀yà tí wọ́n sì yè é.

english: They had to overcome unbelievable pain and suffering.
yoruba: Wọ́n ní láti borí ìnira aláìgbàgbọ́ àti ìyà.

english: Some of them were raising children conceived through rape.
yoruba: Àwọn kan nínú wọn ń tọ́mọ tí wọ́n lóyún wọn látara ìfipábánilòpọ̀.

english: Others were dying slowly with HIV and forgave the perpetrators, who voluntarily infected them using HIV and rape as a weapon.
yoruba: Àwọn mìíràn ń kú díèdíè pẹ̀lú kòkòro apa sójà ara wọ́n sì tún dáríji àwọn tí wọ́n hu ìwà ìbàjẹ́ náà, tí wọ́n fínú-fẹ́dọ̀ kó ààrùn ràn wọn pẹ̀lu lílo kòkòro apa sójà ara àti ìfipábánilòpọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ohun ìjà.

english: So, they inspired me.
yoruba: Nítorí áà, wọ́n ṣe ìwúrí fún mi.

english: If they can do that, I can stay and try to do my best.
yoruba: Tí wọ́n bá lè ṣe ìyẹn, mo lè dúró kí n sì gbìyànjú láti sapá tèmi.

english: Those ladies were really activists of peace and reconciliation.
yoruba: Àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyẹn jẹ́ ajà-fẹ́tọ̀ àlááfíà àti ìparí ìjà.

english: They show us a way to rebuild a country for our children and grandchildren to have, one day, a place they can call home, with pride.
yoruba: Wọ́n fi ọ̀nà kan hàn wá láti ṣe àtúntò orílẹ̀-èdè fún àwọn ọmọ wa àti àrọ́mọdọ́mọ tó ń bọ̀, lọ́jọ́ kan, ibi tí wọ́n lè pè nílé, pẹ̀lú ìyọ ràn.

english: And you can ask yourself where this shift of mindset has brought our country.
yoruba: Ẹ dè lè bi ara yín ibi tí àyípadà èro-ọkàn yìí ti gbé orílẹ̀-ède wa dé.

english: Today in Rwanda, we have the highest percentage of women in parliament.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda lónì, àwa la ní ìdá àwọn obìnrin tó pọ́jù ní ilé-aṣòfin.

english: Wait till I tell you the percentage -- sixty-one percent.
yoruba: Ẹ dúró dìgbà tí màá sọ ìda rẹ̀ fún yín -- ìdá mọ́kàn-lé-láàdọ́ta (61%).

english: In this country, it's 54.
yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè yìí, mẹ́rìn-lè-láàdọ́ta (54) ni.

english: We have reduced child mortality by 75 percent, maternal mortality by 80 percent.
yoruba: A ti mú àdínkù bá ikú ọmọdé pèlú ìdá márùn-lé-láàdọ́rin (75%), ikú ìyá pẹ̀lú ìdá ọgọ́rin (80%).

english: In early 2000s, there were nine women who were dying every day around delivery and pregnancy.
yoruba: Ní ìbèrè àsìko ọdún 2000, àwọn obìnrin mẹ́sàn ni wọ́n ń kú lójoojúmọ́ yíká ìrọbí àti oyún.

english: Today, it's around two.
yoruba: Lónì, ó wà láàrín méjì.

english: It's an unfinished agenda.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́-àgbéṣe tí ò tíì parí ni.

english: We still have a long way to go.
yoruba: Ọ̀na wá ṣì jìn.

english: Two is still too much.
yoruba: Méjì ṣì tún pọ̀jù.

english: But, do I believe that those results are because we had a big number of women in power positions? I do.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n, ṣé mo gbàgbọ́ wí pé àwọn èsì yìí rí bẹ́ẹ̀ nítorí a ní ìdá àwọn obìnrin tó pọ̀ ní ipò agbára? Mo gbà.

english: There is -- yes --there is a study in the developing world that shows that if you improve the status of women, you improve the status of the community where they live.
yoruba: Ó wà -- bẹ́ẹ̀ ni -- ìwádìí kan wà ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ṣì ń dágbà sókè tó fi hàn pé tí ẹ bá mú ìyàtọ̀ bá ipò àwọn obìnrin, ẹ ti mú ìy

english: Up to 47 percent of decrease in child mortality.
yoruba: Àdínkù tó ń lọ bí ìdá mẹ́tà-dín-láàdọ́ta (47%) nínu ikú ọmọdé.

english: And even in this country where we are now, it's true.
yoruba: Kódà ní orílẹ̀-èdè yìí níbi tí a wà báyìí, òótọ́ ni.

english: So we know that women, when they use their skills in leadership positions, they enhance the entire population they are in charge of.
yoruba: Nítorí náà a mọ̀ wí pé àwọn obìnrin, tí wọ́n bá lo ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe wọn ní ipò aṣíwájú, wọ́n máa mú àyípadà bá gbogbo ènìyàn tó wà ní ìkápá wọn.

english: And imagine what would happen if women were at parity with men all over the world.
yoruba: Ẹ wòye ǹkan tí yóò ṣẹlẹ̀ tí àwọn obìnrin bá wà ní ọgba pẹ̀lú àwọn okùnrin káàkiri gbogbo àgbáyé.

english: What a huge benefit we could expect.
yoruba: Ànfàní ńlá wo ni à bá máa retí?

english: Oh, yeah.
yoruba: Oh, Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni.

english: Because in general, we have a different style of leadership: more inclusive, more empathetic, more caring for little children.
yoruba: Tóri ní àpapọ̀, a ní ìṣọwọ́ darí ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀: ọ̀pọ̀ àjùmọ̀ṣe, ọ̀pọ agbára, ọ̀pọ̀ ìtọ́jú fún àwọn ọmọ kékèké.

english: And this makes the difference.
yoruba: Èyí sì fa ìyàtọ̀ náà.

english: Unfortunately, this ideal doesn't exist in the world, and the difference between men and women in leadership positions is too big.
yoruba: Ó ṣeni láànú, èyí tó tọ́ yìí kò sí ní àgbáyá, ìyàtọ̀ tó dẹ̀ wà láàrín àwọn ọkùnrin àti obìnrin nípò aṣíwájú ti tóbi jù.

english: Gender inequity is the norm in the majority of professions, even in global health.
yoruba: Aìsí dédé láàrín okùnrin àti obìnrin ni àṣa nínú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ isẹ́, kóda nínú ètò ìlera-àgbáyé.

english: I have learned that if we focus on women's education, we improve their life positively as well as the well-being of their community.
yoruba: Mo ti kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ pé tí a bá gbájúmọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn obìnrin, a máa mú ìyàtọ̀ bá ìgbeayé wọn gidi gan, bákan náà ni àlàáfíà àwùjọ wọn.

english: This is why now I dedicate my life to education.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyí tí mo fi jọ̀wọ́ ayé mi fún ètò-ẹ̀kọ́.

english: And this is totally aligned with my sense of equity and my pursuit of social justice, because if you want to increase access to health services, you need first to increase access to health education.
yoruba: Èyí wà ní ìṣọ̀kan pẹ̀lú ìrònú mi nípa ìdọ́gba àti lílé dédé àwùjọ, nítorí tí ẹ bá fẹ́ ṣe àfikún ànfàní sí ètò-ìlera, ẹ nílò láti kọ́kọ́ ṣe àfikún ànfàní sí ìmọ̀ ìlera.

english: So with friends and partners, we are building a beautiful university in the rural north of Rwanda.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ ati àwọn alájọṣe, à ń kọ́ fásitì tó rẹwà ní ìgbèríko àríwá orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda.

english: We educate our students to provide quality, equitable, holistic care to everyone, leaving no one out, focusing on the vulnerable, especially women and children, who are historically the last to be served.
yoruba: À ń kọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa láti pèse ojúlówó, adọ́gba, ìtọ́jú àpapọ̀ fún gbogbo ènìyàn, láìyọ ẹnìkẹ́ni sílẹ̀, gbígbájúmọ́ àwọn tó kọ́gun séwu, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn obìnrin àti àwọn ọmọdé, tó ṣe pé nínú ìtàn àwọn ni ẹni ìgbẹ̀yìn láti gba ìtọ́jú.

english: We transform them into leaders and give them managerial skills and advocacy skills for them to be smooth changemakers in the society where they will be, so that they can build health systems that allow them to care about the vulnerable where they are.
yoruba: A ṣe àyípadà wọn sí aṣíwájú a sì fún wọn ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ìṣàmójútó àti ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ìjẹ́ agbẹnusọ kí wọ́n lè ṣe àyípadà tó dán mọ́rán ní àwùjọ tí wọ́n máa wà, kí wọ́n lè pèse ètò ìlera tí yóò gbà wọ́n láyè láti ṣètọ́jú àwọn tó kọ́gun séwu níbi tí wọ́n wà.

english: And it's really transformative.
yoruba: Ó sì ti mú àyípadà wá.

english: Because currently, medical education, for example, is given in institutions based in cities, focused on quality health services and skills, clinical skills, to be given in institutions.
yoruba: Torí lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn, fún àpẹẹrẹ, ni wọ́n ń kọ́ ní àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ tó wà nígboro, tó gbájúmọ́ ojúlówó ètò-ìlera àti ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe, ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ajẹmọ́-ìtọ́jú, tí yóò di gbígbà ní àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́.

english: We also focus on quality clinical skills but with biosocial approach to the condition of patient, for care to be given in communities where the people live, with hospitalization only when necessary.
yoruba: A tún gbájúmọ́ ojúlówó ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ajẹmọ́-ìtọ́jú sùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe àjọṣepọ̀ ìwà àti àwùjọ sí ipò-ìlera àwọn aláìsàn, láti lè ṣe ìtọ́jú ní àwùjọ tí àwọn ènìyàn ń gbé, pẹ̀lú gbígbé lọ sí ilé ìwòsàn nígbà tó bá pọn dandan nìkan.

english: And also, after four to seven years of clinical education in cities, young graduates don't want to go back to rural area.
yoruba: Bákan náà, lẹ́yìn odún mẹ́rin sí méje ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ajẹmọ́-ìwòsàn nígboro, àwọn ọ̀dọ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde ò fẹ́ padà sí àwọn ìgbèríko.

english: So this is why we have built the University of Global Health Equity, an initiative of Partners in Health, called UGHE, in the rural north of Rwanda.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyí tí a fi kọ́ Fásitì Ìdọ́gba Ètò-Ìlera Àgbáyé, ìgbésẹ̀ àwọn alájọṣepọ̀ nínú ètò-ìlera, tí wọ́n pè ní UGHE, ní ìgbèríko àríwá orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda.

english: Our students are meant to go and change the world.
yoruba: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa wà láti mú àyípadà bá àgbáyé.

english: They will come from all over -- it's a global university -- and will get the medical education for free at one condition: they have to serve the vulnerable across the world during six to nine years.
yoruba: Wọn yóò wá láti ibi gbogbo -- fásitì àgbáyé ni -- wọn yóò sì gba ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn lọ́fẹ̀ẹ́ lábẹ́ àdéhùn kan: wọ́n ní láti ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn tó kọ́gun séwu jákèjádò àgbáyé láàrín ọdún mẹ́fà sí mẹ́sàn-án.

english: They will keep the salary for themselves and their families but turn the education we give in quality clinical services, especially for the vulnerable.
yoruba: Wọn yóò tọ́jú owo iṣẹ́ náà fún ara wọn àti àwọn ẹbí wọn ṣùgbọ́n wọn yóò yí ẹ̀kọ́ tí a fún wọn padà sí ojúlówó iṣẹ́ ajẹmọ́-ìwòsàn, pàápàá jùlọ fún àwọn akọ́gun-séwu.

english: And doing so, they sign an agreement at the start that they will do that, a binding agreement.
yoruba: Ṣíṣe eyí, wọn yóò tọwọ́ bọ ìwé àdéhùn ní ìbẹ̀ẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀ pé wọn yóò ṣe ìyẹn, àdéhùn òfin ni.

english: We don't want money.
yoruba: A ò fẹ́ owó.

english: We have to go and mobilize the money.
yoruba: A ní láti lọ pín owó náà yíká.

english: But they will turn this in quality service delivery for all.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọn yóò sọ èyí di ìjábọ̀ iṣẹ́ fún gbogbo ènìyàn.

english: For this, of course, we need a strong gender equity agenda.
yoruba: Fún èyí, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, a nílò ètò ìdọ́gba láàrín ọkùnrin àti obìnrin tó lágbára.

english: And in all our classes, master's course, minimum of 50 percent of women.
yoruba: Ní gbogbo yàrá ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wa, abala ẹ̀kọ́ oyè ìjìnlẹ̀, ó kéré jù ìdá àdọ́ta àwọn obìnrin.

english: And I'm proud to say that for the medical school that started five months ago, we have enrolled 70 percent girls.
yoruba: Inú mi dùn láti sọ pé fún ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn tó bẹ́rẹ̀ ní oṣù márùn-ún sẹ́yìn, a ti gba ìdá àdọ́rin àwọn ọmọdébìnrin.

english: This is a statement against the current inequity for women to access medical education in our continent.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ èsì tako àìdọ́gba lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ fún àwọn obìnrin láti ní ànfàní sí ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn ní ẹkùn wa.

english: I believe in women's education.
yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ nínu ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn obìnrin.

english: This is why I applaud African ladies who go all over the world to increase their education, their skills and their knowledge.
yoruba: Ìdí nìyí tí mo fi gbóríyìn fún àwọn obìnrin nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí wọ́n ń lọ káàkiri àgbáyé láti ṣe àfikún sí ẹ̀kọ́ wọn, ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe wọn àti ìmọ wọn.

english: But I hope they will bring that back to Africa to build the continent and make the continent a strong continent, because I'm sure a stronger Africa will make the world stronger.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo lérò wí pé wọn yóò mú ìyẹn padà wá sílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ láti jẹ́ kí ẹkùn náà gbóórò kí wọn sì sọ ẹkùn náà di agbègbe alágbára, nítorí ó dámi lójú pé ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó lágbára yóò sọ orílẹ̀-èdè àgbáyé di alágbára.

english: Twenty-three years ago, I went back to Rwanda, to a broken Rwanda, that now is still a poor country but shining with a bright future.
yoruba: Ọdún mẹ́tà-lé-lógún sẹ́yìn, mo padà lọ sí orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda, sí orílẹ̀-ède Rwanda tó ti túká, tó ṣì jẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè tó kúṣẹ̀ẹ́ ṣùgbọ́n tó ń tàn pẹ̀lú ọjọ́-iwájú rere.

english: And I am full of joy to have come back, even if some days were very difficult, and even if some days I was depressed, because I didn't find a solution and people were dying, or things were not moving enough.
yoruba: Mo kún fún ayọ̀ láti padà wá, kódà tí àwọn ọjọ́ kan bá le koko, tó sì jẹ́ wí pé àwọn ọjọ́ kan mo ní ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sí, nítorí mi ò rí ọ̀nà àbáyọ àwọn ènìyán sì ń kú, tàbí ǹkan ò lọ dáadáa.

english: But I'm so proud to have contributed to improve my community.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n inú mi dùn láti lọ́wọ́ sí àyípadà àwùjọ mi.

english: And this makes me full of joy.
yoruba: Èyí sì ń jẹ́ kí n kún fáyọ̀.

english: So, African women from the diaspora, if you hear me, never forget your homeland.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, àwọn obìnrin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ láti ilẹ̀-òkèrè, tí ẹ bá ń gbọ́mi, má gbàgbe iléè rẹ.

english: And when you are ready, come back home.
yoruba: Tí ẹ bá ti ṣetán, ẹ padà wálé.

english: I did so.
yoruba: Mo ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: It has fulfilled my life.
yoruba: Ó ti jẹ́ kí ayé mi ní àṣeyọrí.

english: So, come back home.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, ẹ padà wálé.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: How community-led conservation can save wildlife
yoruba: Bí ìkópamọ́ tí àwùjọ léwájú rẹ̀ ṣe lè dóólà àwọn ẹranko igbó.

english: I'm a lion conservationist.
yoruba: Mo jẹ́ olùkópamọ́ kìnìhún.

english: Sounds cool, doesn't it?
yoruba: O dùn-ún gbọ́, àbí bẹ́ẹ̀ kọ́?

english: Some people may have no idea what that means.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn kan lè má nì òye ǹkan tí èyí túmọ̀ sí.

english: But I'm sure you've all heard about Cecil the lion.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó dámi lójú wí pé gbogbo yín lẹ ti gbọ́ nípa Cecil kìnìhún náà.

english: [Cecil the Lion (2002-2015)]
yoruba: [Cecil kìnìhún náà (2002-2015)].

english: (Lion roaring)
yoruba: (kìnìhún tó ń bú ramú-ramù).

english: He roars no more.
yoruba: Kò bú ramú-ramù mọ́

english: On the second of July, 2015, his life was cut short when he was killed by a trophy hunter.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kejì oṣù Agẹmọ, ọdún 2015, wọ́n dá ẹ̀mi rẹ̀ légbodò nígbà tí ọdẹ apẹranko igbó kan pa á.

english: They say that you can become attached to the animals you study.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ wí pé ẹ lè fẹ́ràn ẹranko tí ẹ̀ ń kọ́ nípa rẹ̀.

english: That was the case for me with Cecil the lion, having known him and studied him for three years in Hwange National Park.
yoruba: Bí ó ṣe rí fúnmi àti Cecil kìnìhún náà nìyẹn, lẹ́yìn tí mo ti mọ̀ ọ́ tí mo sì ti mọ̀wa rẹ̀ fún ọdún mẹ́ta ní ààyè-ìgbafẹ́ apapọ̀ Hwange.

english: I was heartbroken at his death.
yoruba: Ikúu rẹ̀ bàmí lọ́kàn jẹ́.

english: But the good thing to come out of this tragedy is the attention that the story brought towards the plight of threatened wild animals.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ǹkan rere kan tó jáde lati ibi àjálù burúkú yìí ni àkíyèsí tí ìtàn yìí múwá nípa ẹ̀hónú àwọn ẹranko igbó tí wọ́n wà nínú ewu.

english: After Cecil's death, I began to ask myself these questions: What if the community that lived next to Cecil the lion was involved in protecting him?
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ikú Cecil, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní bi ara mi ní àwọn ìbéérè wọ̀nyí: ti ó bá jẹ wí pé àwùjọ tí wọ́n ń gbé lẹ́gbẹ kìnìhún náà lọ́wọ́ sí ààbo rẹ̀ ńkọ́?

english: What if I had met Cecil when I was 10 years old, instead of 29?
yoruba: Tó bá ṣe wí pé mo ti mọ Cecil nígbà ti mo wà ní ọmọ ọdún mẹ́wà, yàtọ̀ sí ọmọ ọdún mọ́kàn-dín-lọ́gbọ̀n ńkọ́?

english: Could I or my classmates have changed his fate?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ èmi tàbí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ̀ mi ní yàrá ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìbá ti yí àyànmọ rẹ̀ padà bí?

english: Many people are working to stop lions from disappearing, but very few of these people are native to these countries or from the communities most affected.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ń ṣiṣẹ́ láti dẹ́kun kí kìnìhún ó má pòórá mọ́, ṣùgbọ́n díẹ̀ nínú àwọn ènìyàn wọ̀nyí ni wọ́n jẹ́ ọmọ onílù sí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè wọ̀nyí tàbí láti àwùjọ tí ọ̀rọ́ kàn jù.

english: But the communities that live with the lions are the ones best positioned to help lions the most.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn àwùjọ tí wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lú àwọn kìnìhún náà ni wọ́n wà ní ipò tó dára jù láti ran àwọn kìnìhún náà lọ́wọ́.

english: Local people should be at the forefront of the solutions to the challenges facing their wildlife.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ onílù ló yẹ kí wọ́n léwájúu wíwá ìyanjú sí àwọn ìpèníjà tó ń kojú àwọn ẹranko igbó.

english: Sometimes, change can only come when the people most affected and impacted take charge.
yoruba: Nígbà míràn, àyípadà yóò wáyé nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn tí ọ̀rọ́ kàn tó sì nípa lára wọn jùlọ bá gbà á.

english: Local communities play an important role in fighting poaching and illegal wildlife trade, which are major threats affecting lions and other wildlife.
yoruba: Àwọn àwùjọ ìgbèríko ń kópa pàtàkì láti kojú pípa àti òwo ẹranko igbo lọ́nà àìbófinmu, tí wọ́n jẹ́ olórí ewu tó ń dàmú àwọn kìnìhún àti àwọn ẹranko igbó mìíràn.

english: Being a black African woman in the sciences, the people I meet are always curious to know if I've always wanted to be a conservationist, because they don't meet a lot of conservationists who look like me.
yoruba: Pé mo jẹ́ obìnrin aláwọ̀-dúdú ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nínú ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀, àwọn ènìyàn tí mo máa ń pàdá máa ń nífẹ̀ láti mọ̀ bóyá ó wùnmí láti jẹ́ olùkó pamọ́ ni, nítorí wọn kìí pàdé àwọn olùkópamọ́ tí wọ́n jọmi lọ̀pọ̀lọpò.

english: When I was growing up, I didn't even know that wildlife conservation was a career.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà, mi ò tiẹ̀ mọ̀ wí pé iṣẹ́-ìṣe ni ìkópamọ́ àwọn ẹranko igbó.

english: The first time I saw a wild animal in my home country was when I was 25 years old, even though lions and African wild dogs lived just a few miles away from my home.
yoruba: Ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí mo rí ẹranko igbó ní orílẹ̀-èdè mi nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọ ọdún mẹ́ẹ̀dọ́gbọ̀n, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé kìnìhún àti àwọn ajá igbó ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ń gbé ní ibùsọ̀ díẹ̀ sí ilé mi.

english: This is quite common in Zimbabwe, as many people are not exposed to wildlife, even though it's part of our heritage.
yoruba: Èyí wọ́pọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Zimbabwe, nítorí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ò lajú sí ẹranko igbó, bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé ó wà lára àṣa wa.

english: When I was growing up, I didn't even know that lions lived in my backyard.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà, mi ò tilẹ̀ mọ̀ wí pé kìnìhún ń gbé lẹ́yìn ilé mi.

english: When I stepped into Sav├® Valley Conservancy on a cold winter morning 10 years ago to study African wild dogs for my master's research project, I was mesmerized by the beauty and the tranquility that surrounded me.
yoruba: Nígbà tí mo dásẹ̀ wọ Savé Valley Conservancy ní àárọ̀ ọlọ́gínìtì kan ní ọdún mẹ́wà sẹ́yìn láti kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa àwọn ajá igbó ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ fún iṣẹ́ ìwádì oyè ìjìnlẹ̀ mi, ẹwà àti ìdákẹ́rọ́rọ́ tó yími ká fàmí mọ́ra.

english: I felt like I had found my passion and my purpose in life.
yoruba: Ó dàbi ẹni pé mo ti rí ohun tí mo nífẹ̀ sí àti àyànmọ́ mi nílé ayé.

english: I made a commitment that day that I was going to dedicate my life to protecting animals.
yoruba: Mo ṣe ìpinnu lọ́jọ́ náà pé màá fi gbogbo ayé mi dáábò bo àwọn ẹranko.

english: I think of my childhood school days in Zimbabwe and the other kids I was in school with.
yoruba: Mo ronú nípa àwọn ìgbà tí mo wà ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ èwe ní orílẹ̀-ède Zimbabwe àti àwọn ọmọ tókù tí a jọ wà ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́.

english: Perhaps if we had a chance to interact with wildlife, more of my classmates would be working alongside me now.
yoruba: Bóyá tí a bá ti ní ànfàní láti farakínra pẹ̀lú ẹranko igbó ni, ọ̀pọ̀ nínú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ mi ní yàrá ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni a ó jọ máa ṣiṣẹ́ báyìí.

english: Unless the local communities want to protect and coexist with wildlife, all conservation efforts might be in vain.
yoruba: Àyàfi tí àwọn àwùjọ ìgbèríko bá fẹ́ dáábòbò tí wọ́n sì fẹ́ gbé pẹ̀lú ẹranko igbó, gbogbo ìgbìyànjú olùkópamọ́ lè já sásán.

english: These are the communities that live with the wild animals in the same ecosystem and bear the cost of doing so.
yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí ni àwùjọ tí wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹranko igbó náà ní àyíká kan náà tí wọ́n sì ń fara gbá ṣíṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: If they don't have a direct connection or benefit from the animals, they have no reason to want to protect them.
yoruba: Tí wọn ò bá ní àjọṣepọ̀ tààrà tàbí ànfàní látara àwọn ẹranko náà, wọn ò ní ìdí kankan láti dáábò bò wọ́n.

english: And if local communities don't protect their wildlife, no amount of outside intervention will work.
yoruba: Tí àwọn àwùjọ ìgbèríko ò bá dáábò bo ẹranko igbó wọn, kò sí iye ìdásí láti ìta tí yóò ṣiṣẹ́.

english: So what needs to be done?
yoruba: Nítorí náà kí la nílò láti ṣe?

english: Conservationists must prioritize environmental education and help expand the community's skills to conserve their wildlife.
yoruba: Àwọn olùkópamọ́ gbọ́dọ̀ mú ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ agbègbè lọ́kùkúdùn kí wọ́n sì ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ láti gbòòro ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe àwùjọ láti ṣe ìpamọ́ àwọn ẹranko igbó wọn.

english: Schoolchildren and communities must be taken to national parks, so they get a chance to connect with the wildlife.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ àti àwùjọ gbọ́dọ̀ di mímú lọ sí àwọn àyè-ìgbafẹ́ àpapọ̀, kí wọ́n lè ní ànfàní láti ní ìbáṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ẹranko igbó.

english: At every effort and every level, conservation must include the economies of the people who share the land with the wild animals.
yoruba: Fún gbogbo ìgbìyànjú àti gbogbo ìpele, ìkópamọ́ gbọ́dọ̀ pẹ̀lu ọrọ̀-ajé àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n jìjọ ń pín ilẹ̀ lò pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹranko igbó.

english: It is also critical that local conservationists be part of every conservation effort, if we are to build trust and really embed conservation into communities.
yoruba: Ó tún ṣe pàtàkì pé kí àwọn olùkópamọ́ agbègbè wà lára gbogbo ìgbìyànjú ìkópamọ́, tí a bá fẹ́ kí wọ́n gbà wá gbọ́ tí a sì fẹ́ fi ìkópamọ́ rinlẹ̀ sí àwùjọ lóòtọ́.

english: As local conservationists, we face many hurdles, from outright discrimination to barriers because of cultural norms.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi olùkópamọ́ agbègbè, a máa ń kojú ìṣòro tó pọ̀, láti ibi ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà sí àwọn ìṣòro nítorí àṣà àti ìṣe.

english: But I will not give up my efforts to bring indigenous communities to this fight for the survival of our planet.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò ní jáwọ́ ìgbìyànjú mi láti mú àwọn ènìyàn àwùjọ wọlé láti ja ìjà yìí fún ìmóríbọ́ àgbáyé wa.

english: I'm asking you to come and stand together with me.
yoruba: Mò ń pè yín láti wá darapọ̀ pẹ̀lú mi.

english: We must actively dismantle the hurdles we have created, which are leaving indigenous populations out of conservation efforts.
yoruba: A gbọ́dọ̀ jọ tú àwọn ìṣòro tí a ti ṣèdá ká, tó ń yọwọ́ àwọn ọmọ-ìlú kúrò nínu ìgbìyànjú ìkópamọ̀.

english: I've dedicated my life to protecting lions.
yoruba: Mo ti jọ̀wọ ayé mi fún ìdáábò bo kìnìhún.

english: And I know my neighbor would, too, if only they knew the animals that lived next door to them.
yoruba: Mo dẹ̀ mọ̀ pé àwọn alájọgbé mi yóò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, bákan náà, ìbá ṣe wí pé wọ́n mọ àwọn ẹranko tí ó ń gbé ní ẹ̀gbẹ wọn ni.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: How cancer cells communicate - and how we can slow them down
yoruba: Bí àwọn hóró àìsan jẹjẹrẹ ṣe ń sọ̀rọ̀ - àti bí a ṣelè mú wọn wálẹ̀.

english: It's a devastating disease that takes an enormous emotional toll.
yoruba: Ààrùn tó ń bani láye jẹ́ ni tó sì ń bani lọ́kàn jẹ́.

english: Not only on the patient, but the patient's loved ones, as well.
yoruba: Kìí se fún aláìsàn nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n àwọn olólùfẹ aláìsàn náà, bákan náà.

english: It is a battle that the human race has been fighting for centuries.
yoruba: Ogun tí ìran ọmọ ènìyàn ti ń jà fún àìmọye ọ̀rún-ọdún ni.

english: And while we've made some advancements, we still haven't beaten it.
yoruba: Nígbà tí a ti ṣe àwọn ìtẹ̀síwájú kan, a ò tíì ṣẹ́gun rẹ̀.

english: Two out of five people in the US will develop cancer in their lifetime.
yoruba: Méjì nínú ènìyàn márùn-ún ní orílẹ̀-ède US ni yóò ní àìsan jẹjẹrẹ ní ìṣẹ̀mi wọn.

english: Of those, 90 percent will succumb to the disease due to metastases.
yoruba: Nínú àwọn wọ̀nyí, ìdá àdọ́rùn (90%) yóò juwọ́lẹ̀ fún ààrùn yìí nítorí ìtànka rẹ̀.

english: Metastasis is a spread of cancer from a primary site to a distal site, through the circulatory or the lymphatic system.
yoruba: Ìtànká jẹ́ ìfọ́nká àìsan jẹjẹrẹ láti àyè ìpìlẹ̀ sí àyè míràn, nípasẹ̀ ètò ìṣàn-ẹ̀jẹ̀ tàbí ètò omi-ara.

english: For instance, a female patient with breast cancer doesn't succumb to the disease simply because she has a mass on her breast.
yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, obìnrin aláìsàn pẹ̀lu àìsan jẹjẹrẹ ọyàn kìí juwọ́lẹ̀ fún ààrùn náà nítorí ó pọ̀ lórí ọyàn rẹ̀.

english: She succumbs to the disease because it spreads to the lungs, liver, lymph nodes, brain, bone, where it becomes unresectable or untreatable.
yoruba: Ó juwọ́lẹ̀ fún ààrùn náà nítorí ó ń tàn lọ sí ẹ̀dọ̀-fóró, ẹ̀dọ̀, asẹ́ omi-ara, ọpọlọ, egungun, níbi tí kò ní ṣe é fi iṣẹ́ abẹ yọ tàbí ṣeé tọ́jú.

english: Metastasis is a complicated process.
yoruba: Ìtànká jẹ́ ìgbésẹ̀ àmúdijú.

english: One that I've studied for several years now.
yoruba: Èyí tí mo ti ń kọ́ nípa rẹ̀ fún àìmọye ọdún báyìí.

english: And something that my team and I discovered recently was that cancer cells are able to communicate with each other and coordinate their movement, based on how closely packed they are in the tumor microenvironment.
yoruba: Ǹkan tí èmi àti ikò mi ṣàwárí láìpẹ́ yìí ni wí pé àwọn hóró àìsan jẹjẹrẹ máa ń bá ara wọn sọ̀rọ̀ wọ́n sì máa ń dari ètò ìgbésẹ̀ wọn, lóri bí wọ́n ṣe súnmọ́ra wọn nínu agbègbè-àìfojúrí kókó.

english: They communicate with each other through two signaling molecules called Interleukin-6 and Interleukin-8.
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń bára wọn sọ̀rọ̀ nípasẹ̀ mólékù afúnilọ́wọ́ méjì tí wọ́n ń pè ní Interleukin-6 àti Interleukin-8.

english: Now, like anything else in nature, when things get a little too tight, the signal is enhanced, causing the cancer cells to move away faster from the primary site and spread to a new site.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, bí ǹkan mìíràn nínu ẹ̀dá, tí ǹkan bá fún díẹ̀, ó máa ń ran àmì náà lọ́wọ́, tí yóó sì mú kí àwọn hóró àìsan jẹjẹrẹ náà yára sún kúrò láti àyè-ìpìlẹ̀ kí wọ́n sì fọ́nká sí àyè tuntun.

english: So, if we block this signal, using a drug cocktail that we developed, we can stop the communication between cancer cells and slow down the spread of cancer.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, tí a bá dí àmì yìí, pèlu lílo ògun kan tí a pèsè, a lè dá ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ láàrín àwọn hóró àìsan jẹjẹrẹ dúró ká sì mú àdínkù bá ìfọ́nká àìsan jẹjẹrẹ.

english: Let me pause here for a second and take you back to when this all began for me in 2010, when I was just a sophomore in college.
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n dánu dúró díẹ̀ fún ìṣẹ́jú àyá kan kí n sì mu yín padà sí ìgbà tí gbogbo èyí bẹ̀rẹ̀ fún mi ní ọdún 2010, nígbà tí mo jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ odún kejì ní ilé-ìwé gíga.

english: I had just started working in Dr Danny Wirtz's lab at Johns Hopkins University.
yoruba: Mo ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ṣiṣẹ́ ní àyè fún àyẹ̀wo ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ omímọ̀ ìṣègùn Danny Wirtz ní fásitì John Hopkins ni.

english: And I'll be honest: I was a young, naive, Sri Lankan girl, who had no previous research experience.
yoruba: Màá dẹ̀ ṣe òótọ́: mo jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́, aláìmọ̀kan, ọmọdébìnrin Sri Lankan, tí ò ní ìrírí ìwádìí àtẹ̀yìnwá Kankan.

english: And I was tasked to look at how cancer cells move in a 3D collagen I matrix that recapsulated, in a dish, the conditions that cancer cells are exposed to in our bodies.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n gbé fún mi ni láti wo bí àwọn hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ ṣe ń rìn ní 3D collagen I matrix tó máa ń ṣàfihàn, nínu abọ́ kan, ipò tí àwọn hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ ń kojú lára wa.

english: This was new and exciting for me, because previous work had been done on 2D, flat, plastic dishes that really weren't representative of what the cancer cells are exposed to in our bodies.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ tuntun ó sì ń fún mi láyò, nítorí àwọn iṣẹ́ àtẹ̀yìnwá ni wọ́n ti ṣe lóri 2D, pẹlẹbẹ, abọ́ oníke tí wọn kìí fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe àgbéjáde ǹkan tí àwọn hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ ń kojú lára wa.

english: Because, let's face it, the cancer cells in our bodies aren't stuck onto plastic dishes.
yoruba: Nítorí, ẹ jẹ́ ká dojú kọ ọ́, àwọn hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ nínú ara wa kìí dúró lórí àwọn abọ́ oníke.

english: It was during this time that I attended a seminar conducted by Dr Bonnie Bassler from Princeton University, where she talked about how bacteria cells communicate with each other, based on their population density, and perform a specific action.
yoruba: Ní àsìkò yìí ni mo lọ sí sẹminá tí Oníṣégùn-òyìnbó Bonnie Bassler láti fásitì Princeton gbé kalẹ̀, níbi tó ti sọ̀rọ̀ nípa bí àwọn hóró alámọ̀ ṣe ń bára wọn sọ̀rọ̀, lóri iye àgbáríjọpọ̀ wọn, tí wọ́n sì ń ṣe àwọn iṣẹ́ kan pàtó.

english: It was at this moment that a light bulb went off in my head, and I thought, "Wow, I see this in my cancer cells every day, when it comes to their movement.
yoruba: Àsìkò yìí ni iná kan dédé kú lórí mi, mo wá rò ó, "Wow, mo máa ń rí èyí nínu hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ mi lójoojúmọ́, tí a bá ń sọ nípa ìgbésẹ̀ wọn.

english: The idea for my project was thus born.
yoruba: Èro iṣẹ́-àkànṣe mi bá di bíbí.

english: I hypothesized that cancer cells are able to communicate with each other and coordinate their movement, based on how closely packed they are in the tumor microenvironment.
yoruba: Mo ṣe àròsọ pé àwọn hóró ààrun jẹjẹrẹ máa ń bára wọn sọ̀rọ̀ wọ́n sì máa ń darí ìgbésẹ̀ wọn, lóri bí wọ́n ṣe jọ wà papọ̀ ní àwùjọ-àìfojúrí kókó.

english: I became obsessed with pursuing this hypothesis.
yoruba: Mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ronú pẹ̀lu ìṣiṣẹ́ tọ àròsọ yìí.

english: And fortunately, I work for someone who is open to running with my crazy ideas.
yoruba: Orí bámi ṣé, mò ń ṣisẹ́ fún ẹnìkan tó ṣetán láti ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú èrò tó ń sín mi níwín.

english: So, I threw myself into this project.
yoruba: Nítorí náà, mo jura mi sínu iṣẹ́-àkànṣe yìí.

english: However, I couldn't do it by myself.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, mi ò lè dáṣe é fúnra mi.

english: I needed help.
yoruba: Mo nílò ìrànlọ́wọ́.

english: I definitely needed help.
yoruba: Mo nílò ìrànlọ́wọ́ lóòtọ́.

english: So we recruited undergraduate students, graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and professors from different institutions and multiple disciplines to come together and work on this idea that I conceived as a sophomore in college.
yoruba: A gba àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí wọn ò tíì kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́-jáde, àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé àti àwọn ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n láti ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ lóríṣiríṣi àti oríṣiríṣi ẹ̀ka láti parapọ̀ ṣiṣẹ́ lórí èrò yìí tí mo lóyún rẹ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi akẹ́kẹ̀ọ́ odún kejì nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

english: After years of conducting experiments together and merging different ideas and perspectives, we discovered a new signaling pathway that controls how cancer cells communicate with each other and move, based on their cell density.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn àìmọye odún tí a tí ń ṣe ìdánwò papọ̀ tí a sì ń pa oríṣiríṣi èrò àti òye pọ̀, a ṣàwárí orípa ìṣàmì tuntun tó ń daríi bí àwọn hó

english: Some of you might have heard this, because most of social media knows it as the Hasini effect.
yoruba: Àwọn kan nínu yín lè ti gbọ́ èyí, nítorí ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ìkànì ìbánidọ́rẹ̀ mọ̀ ọ́ sí ipa Hasini.

english: And we weren't done yet.
yoruba: A ò dẹ̀ tíì ṣetán.

english: We then decided that we wanted to block this signaling pathway and see if we could slow down the spread of cancer.
yoruba: A wá pinnu wí pé a fẹ́ dí orípa ìsàmì ká wá wò ó bóyá a lè mú àdínkù bá ìfọ́nká ààrun jẹjẹrẹ.

english: Which we did, in preclinical animal models.
yoruba: Tí a dẹ̀ ṣe, ní àwòṣe ìtọ́jú ṣíwáju àyẹ̀wò lára ẹranko.

english: We came up with a drug cocktail consisting of tocilizumab, which is currently used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, and reparixin, which is currently in clinical trials against breast cancer.
yoruba: A pèsè òògùn aládálù kan tó ní tocilizumab, tí a ń lò lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ láti tọ́jú làkúrégbè, àti reparixin, tí à ń lò lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ fún ìwádìí ajẹmọ́-ìtọ́jú ààrun jẹjẹrẹ ọyàn.

english: And interestingly, what we found was that this cocktail of drugs really had no effect on tumor growth, but directly targeted metastases.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìdùnú, nkan tí a rí ni wí pé òògun aládálù yìí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ nípa lára ìdàgbàsókè kókó, ṣùgbọ́n ó dojúkọ ìtànká tààrà.

english: This was a significant finding, because currently, there aren't any FDA-approved therapeutics that directly target the spread of cancer.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ àbájáde tó ṣe pàtàkì, torí lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, kò sí òògun FDA kankan tó gbàṣẹ tó ń kojú ìtànká ààrun jẹjẹrẹ tààrà.

english: In fact, the spread of cancer, metastasis, is thought of as a byproduct of tumor growth.
yoruba: Lóòtọ́, ìtànká ààrun jẹjẹrẹ, títànká, ní wọ́n ń ri gẹ́gẹ́ bi èròjà ìdàgbàsókè kókó.

english: Where the idea is, if we can stop the tumor from growing, we can stop the tumor from spreading.
yoruba: Níbi tí èrò náà wà, tí a bá lè dènà ìdàgbàsókè kókó, a lè dèna ìtànká kókó.

english: However, most of us know that this is not true.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ wa mọ̀ wí pé èyí kìí ṣe òótọ́.

english: We, on the other hand, came up with the drug cocktail that targets metastasis not by targeting tumor growth, but by targeting the complex mechanisms that govern it, through the targeting of the Hasini effect.
yoruba: Àwa, nídà kejì, pèse ògùn olómi kan tó ń kojú ìtànká tí kìí ṣe pẹ̀lú ìdojúkọ ìdàgbàsókè kókó, ṣùgbọ́n pẹ̀lú ìdojúkọ ìṣẹ̀dá tó gbóórò tó ń darí rẹ̀, nípasẹ̀ kíkojú ipa Hasini.

english: This work was recently published in "Nature Communications," and my team and I received an overwhelming response from around the world.
yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe àtẹ̀jáde iṣẹ́ yìí láìpẹ́ yìí nínu "Nature Communications," èmi àti àwọn ikò mi dẹ̀ gba èsì tó pọ̀ káàkiri àgbáyé.

english: Nobody on my team could have predicted this sort of response.
yoruba: Kò sí ẹnìkẹ́ni nínu ikọ̀ mi tó lè sọ àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ irú àwọn èsì yìí.

english: We seem to have struck a nerve.
yoruba: Ó jọ bí ẹni pé a ti kan ǹkan.

english: Looking back, I am extremely grateful for the positive response that I received, not only from academia, but also patients, and people around the world affected by this terrible disease.

english: The graduate students and the postdoctoral fellows, my fellow Avengers, who taught me new techniques and always made sure I stayed on track.

english: The professors, my Yodas and my Obi-Wan Kenobis, who brought their expertise into making this work into what it is today.

english: The best kind of sidekicks we could have asked for.

english: Today, our team has grown, and we are using the Hasini effect to develop combination therapies that will effectively target tumor growth and metastases.
yoruba: Lónì, ikọ̀ wa ti dàgbà, a sì ń lo ipa Hasini láti pèse àkójọpọ̀ òògùn tó máa kojú ìdàgbàsókè kókó àti ìtànká.

english: We are engineering new anticancer therapeutics, to limit toxicity and to reduce drug resistance.

english: It blows my mind to think that all this, the incredible work that I'm pursuing -- and the fact that I'm standing here, talking to you today -- all came from this tiny idea that I had when I was sitting at the back of a seminar when I was just 20 years old.

english: I recognize that right now, I am on this incredible journey that allows me to pursue work that I am extremely passionate about, and something that feeds my curiosity on a daily basis.
yoruba: Mo mọ ìyẹn nísinyìí, mo wà lóri ìrìn-àjò aláìlẹ́gbẹ́ yìí tó fún mi ní ànfàní láti ṣiṣẹ́ tọ iṣẹ́ tí mo nífẹ̀ sí, àti ǹkan tó máa ń bọ́ ìmọ̀ mi lójoojúmọ́.

english: But I have to say, my favorite part of all of this -- other than, of course, being here, talking to you, today -- is the fact that I get to work with a diverse group of people, who make my work stronger, better and just so much more fun.

english: And it is the superpower that we can all turn to to inspire us to create something bigger than ourselves, that will help make the world a better place.

english: Collaboration is the superpower that I turn to, to help me fight cancer.
yoruba: Àjọṣepọ̀ ni agbára-àkàndá tí mo kọjú sí, láti bá mi jagún ààrun jẹjẹrẹ.

english: And I am confident that with the right collaborations, we will beat this terrible disease.
yoruba: Mo dẹ̀ ní ìdánilójú pé pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ tó tọ́, a máa ṣègun ààrùn burúkú yìí.

english: Thank you.

yoruba: Ẹ lè máa dókówò sí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ sìgá láìmọ̀.

english: In 2001, I was a brand new, shiny doctor, planning to save the world.
yoruba: Ní ọdún 2001, mo jẹ́ oníṣégùn-òyìnbó tuntun àyọ́rán, tó ń dán, tó ń gbérò láti gba ayé là.

english: My first job was working for three months on a lung cancer unit.

english: And despite living in a beautiful, wealthy country, with access to the most sophisticated medicines, nearly every single one of my patients died.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lu pé wọ́n ń gbé ní orílẹ̀-ède tó rẹwà, tó rọrọ̀, pẹ̀lú ànfàní sí àwọn òògùn tó lágbára jù, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé ìkànkan gbogbo àwọn aláìsàn mi ni wọ́n kú tán.

english: Everyone knows tobacco is bad, but when you see the impact firsthand, day-by-day, it leaves a very deep impression.
yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyàn ló mọ̀ wí pé kùkúyè ò dára, ṣùgbọ́n tí ẹ bá rí ipa rẹ̀ tààrà, tọ́jọ́ ń gorí ọjọ́, ó máa ń fi ipa tó kẹnú sílẹ̀.

english: Ten years later, I'm a radiation oncologist, fully aware of the suffering caused by tobacco.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọdún mẹ́wà, onímọ̀ nípa ìtàn ikókó ni mí, tó mọ̀ nípa ìnira tí kùkúyè ń fà.

english: I'm sitting at the hospital cafeteria, having my first ever meeting with a representative from my superannuation fund.
yoruba: Mo jókòó sí ilé-oúnjẹ ilé-ìwòsàn, mò ń ṣe ìpàdé mi àkọ́kọ́ pẹ̀lú aṣojú kan láti ilé-iṣẹ́ owó-ìfẹ̀yìntì mi.

english: It was thrilling, I'm sure you can imagine.
yoruba: Ó múnú mi dùn, ó dámi lójú pé ẹ lè wòye rẹ̀.

english: He tells me I'm in the default option.

yoruba: Mo ní, "Ẹ̀yàn?

yoruba: Mo ní, "Ǹjẹ́ o dárúkọ kùkúyè?

english: And he said, "Oh, yes, everyone is.
yoruba: Ó ní, "oh, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, gbogbo ènìyàn sì ni.

english: You want that company to grow and succeed and thrive.
yoruba: O fẹ́ kí ilé-iṣẹ́ yẹn gbòòrò kó ṣe àṣeyọrí kó sì gbèrú.

english: You want that company to attract new customers, you want that company to sell more of its products.
yoruba: O fẹ́ kí ilé-iṣẹ́ yẹn fa ojú àwọn oníbàárà tuntun mọ́ra, o fẹ́ kí ilé-iṣẹ́ yẹn ta ọ̀pọ̀ nínu àwọn èròjà rẹ̀.

english: And when it comes to tobacco, I couldn't think of anything that I wanted less.
yoruba: Tí ó bá sì jẹ́ ti kùkúyè, mi ò lè ronú ǹkankan tí mo fẹ́ tó yátọ̀.

english: Now, I know you can only see one person standing here on this big red dot, on this enormous stage.
yoruba: Ní báyìí, mo mọ̀ wí pé ẹnikan tó dúró lóri àmì pupa yìí nìkan ni ẹ̀ ń rí, lórí ìtàgé ńlá yìí.

english: But instead, I would like you to imagine that you're looking at seven million people crammed up here beside me today.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n dípo bẹ́ẹ̀, màá fẹ́ kí ẹ rò ó wí pé ẹ̀ ń wo mílíọ́nù méje ènìyàn tí wọ́n fúnpò ní ẹ̀gbẹ́ mi níbí lónì.

english: Seven million people across the world have died as a result of tobacco in the past year alone.

english: Just imagine, if a brand new industry were launched today, and by the end of next June, that industry's products had killed seven million people.

english: Would any of us invest in that new, deadly industry?

english: Tobacco is one of the most pressing global issues of our time, and most of us are far more complicit in the problem than we may realize.

english: So I asked him, "Well, which international shares do I have?

english: Finance leaders have many challenging issues to deal with, these days.
yoruba: Àwọn adarí owó ní oríṣiríṣi ìpeníjà láti kojú, lásíkò yìí.

english: So I suggest they adopt a framework that clearly articulates why it is reasonable to take a strong position on tobacco.

english: I suggest finance leaders ask a suite of three questions of any company in which they might invest our money.

english: Question one: Can the product made by the company be used safely?

english: The treaty was created because of the catastrophic global impact of tobacco.
yoruba: Wọ́n ṣẹ̀da àdéhùn náà nítorí ipa ewu kùkúyè lágbàyé.

english: One billion deaths.
yoruba: Bílíọ́nù ikú kan.

english: There's only seven billion of us.
